acts.summary: You settle into your new role as the village baker, getting acquainted with your bakery and meeting key characters like your quirky landlord and the chatty postmistress. The act focuses on establishing yourself in the community and learning the ropes of running the bakery.
acts.title: A Fresh Start in Applebottom
acts.description: Welcome to your new life as the village baker in the charming English hamlet of Applebottom. As you settle into your cosy bakery on High Street, you'll meet your gregarious landlord, Mr Pemberton, who's always ready with a friendly word and a helping hand. The chatty postmistress, Miss Tilly, will keep you up-to-date on all the local gossip while you learn the ins and outs of running your own bakery. Immerse yourself in the tight-knit community and discover the joys and challenges of being Applebottom's newest resident.
problems: The bakery oven won't light on your first day open for business.
The bakery till is jammed shut with old toffees from the previous owner.
A batch of scones comes out hard as rocks and inedible.
Loud banging noises are coming from the plumbing in the bakery walls.
A mouser kitten becomes trapped in the bakery wall.

challenges.name: The Obstinate Oven
challenges.description: It's your grand opening day, but as you turn the knob on the ancient bakery oven, it refuses to light. Mr Pemberton had assured you it was in tip-top shape! Better find a way to get it going before your first customers arrive.

challenges.name: Toffee Trouble
challenges.description: As you go to ring up your first sale, you realise the till is jammed shut, gummed up by a wad of sticky toffees wedged in the mechanism. Looks like the previous owner had a sweet tooth! You'll need to find a way to dislodge the gooey mess.

challenges.name: Scone Scandal
challenges.description: Miss Tilly pops round for elevenses, eager to sample your freshly baked scones. But as you take them out of the oven, they're hard as rocks and utterly inedible! How can you soften these into something palatable before word gets around about your baking blunder?

challenges.name: Plumbing Pandemonium
challenges.description: A loud banging noise startles you awake at the crack of dawn. It seems to be coming from inside the bakery walls - likely the old plumbing acting up again. But the racket is sure to disturb the neighbours if you don't quiet it down soon!

challenges.name: Kitty Conundrum
challenges.description: Pesky mice are always finding their way into the bakery walls. But this time, your adorable new mouser kitten, Gingersnap, has become trapped in there too while on the prowl. You can hear her plaintive meows through the wall. You'll need something slim and firm to coax her out.

acts.summary: You take on catering a grand garden party at the manor house, working closely with the eccentric lady of the manor. This act explores the social hierarchy of the village and the challenge of meeting the expectations of the gentry while staying true to your humble baking style.
acts.title: A Taste of High Society
acts.description: You've made a name for yourself in Applebottom, and now you've been invited to cater the grand garden party at Rosehill Manor. Lady Beatrice Wentworth, the eccentric and demanding lady of the manor, has taken a keen interest in your baking skills. As you navigate the opulent halls and pristine gardens of the manor, you'll need to find a way to impress the gentry with your creations while staying true to your humble roots. Can you rise to the occasion and prove that you're the perfect baker for the job?
problems: The oven at Rosehill Manor is an unfamiliar, old-fashioned model that heats unevenly.
Right before the guests arrive, you accidentally spill raspberry jam on your white apron.
The antique china platter meant to serve the centrepiece lemon tart has gone missing.
The Earl's mischievous hunting dog snatches a tray of freshly baked currant scones.
You unintentionally offend the imperious Dowager Countess at the formal tea service.

challenges.name: Mastering the Oven
challenges.description: Lady Beatrice's prized antique oven is a temperamental beast, prone to hot spots and uneven baking. You'll need to find a way to tame this cranky relic if you hope to impress the manor's discerning guests with your perfectly browned bakes.

challenges.name: A Stitch in Time
challenges.description: Disaster strikes moments before the guests are due to arrive - you've accidentally spilt sticky raspberry jam all over your pristine white apron! Lady Beatrice will be appalled if she sees you in such a state. Quick, you must find a way to clean or conceal the stain before it's too late.

challenges.name: The Case of the Missing Platter
challenges.description: The antique china platter, an heirloom of the Wentworth family, has vanished without a trace. It's meant to be the centrepiece of the dessert table, displaying your prized lemon tart. You'll need to track down the missing platter or find a suitable replacement before the tart is served.

challenges.name: The Purloined Pastries
challenges.description: Just as you pull a tray of freshly baked currant scones from the oven, the Earl's rambunctious hunting dog bounds into the kitchen and snatches them in his jaws! You watch helplessly as the dog races out into the garden with your hard work. You'll have to retrieve the scones or bake a new batch posthaste.

challenges.name: Hell Hath No Fury
challenges.description: Oh crumbs, you've put your foot in it now! An offhand remark about the Dowager Countess's hat has left the imperious matriarch in a frightful huff. Find a way to get back in her good graces, or risk your chance at becoming the manor's go-to baker.

acts.summary: The annual village fête is approaching, and you are tasked with organising the baking competition. This act delves into the competitive spirit among the villagers and the pressure of being both a participant and a judge in the contest.
acts.title: A Recipe for Rivalry
acts.description: The annual Applebottom Village Fête is just around the corner, and as the village baker, you've been tasked with organising the highly anticipated baking competition. As you prepare your own entries, you'll need to navigate the fierce rivalry among the villagers, each determined to prove their baking prowess. With the vicar, the postmistress, and even Lady Beatrice vying for the top prize, you'll have to balance your role as both a participant and a judge, all while ensuring the fête is a resounding success.
problems: Repair the village hall's malfunctioning oven before the competition begins.
Adapt your baking entries to accommodate a contestant's food allergy without compromising taste.
Procure additional baking supplies when a contestant accidentally destroys their own ingredients.
Improvise a solution when a power outage threatens to disrupt the competition.
Find a way to showcase the competition entries when the display table collapses.

challenges.name: Not Again
challenges.description: The ancient oven in the village hall has decided to break down just hours before the baking competition begins. As the organiser, it falls to you to get it working again, or the fête will be ruined before it even starts.

challenges.name: Baking for Tommy
challenges.description: Young Tommy Higgins, the vicar's nephew, has a severe nut allergy, but he's determined to participate in juding the competition. You'll need to modify your award-winning recipes to ensure Tommy can safely enjoy the treats without sacrificing any of the deliciousness.

challenges.name: Miss Pemberton's Mishap
challenges.description: In a moment of clumsiness, Miss Penelope Pemberton, the village postmistress, has knocked over her carefully prepared ingredients, rendering them unusable. With the competition just hours away, you must find a way to procure additional supplies for her, or risk losing one of the most enthusiastic participants.

challenges.name: Stormy Baking Weather
challenges.description: A sudden summer thunderstorm has caused a power outage throughout the village, threatening to plunge the baking competition into darkness. You'll need to find an alternative source of light and heat to keep the event running smoothly and ensure all the baked goods are properly prepared.

challenges.name: The Great Table Collapse
challenges.description: Just as the judging is about to begin, the rickety old display table holding the competition entries collapses, sending cakes and pastries tumbling to the ground. You must quickly devise a new way to showcase the baked goods and prevent the entire competition from ending in disaster.

acts.summary: As the holidays approach, you receive a special request from the vicar to create a unique treats for the Christmas Eve service. This act centres on the role of tradition and faith in the community, as well as your character's personal growth and creative expression as a baker.
acts.title: A Christmas Confection
acts.description: As the festive season approaches, the vicar of St. Bartholomew's Church has a special request for you, the village baker. He asks you to create a unique selection of treats for the Christmas Eve service, a beloved tradition in Applebottom. This is your chance to showcase your creativity and express your growing connection to the community. As you work on this meaningful task, you'll reflect on your journey as the village baker and the friendships you've formed along the way.
problems: You need to create a festive centrepiece cake that represents the spirit of Applebottom.
You accidentally overbake a tray of gingerbread biscuits and need to find a way to salvage them.
You realise you've run out of festive packaging materials to present the treats attractively.
You need to transport the delicate chocolate decorations you've prepared to the church without damaging them.
A sudden cold snap makes it difficult to keep your gingerbread house from falling apart.

challenges.name: The Spirit of Applebottom Cake
challenges.description: Vicar Percival has asked you to create a centrepiece cake for the Christmas Eve service that captures the essence of Applebottom. Drawing inspiration from your interactions with the villagers and your own cherished memories, design a cake that will delight the congregation and fill everyone with festive cheer.

challenges.name: Gingerbread Biscuit Revival
challenges.description: Oh no! In the hustle and bustle of the Christmas rush, you've accidentally overbaked a batch of gingerbread biscuits. Rather than letting them go to waste, use your creativity and ingenuity to transform these crisp biscuits into a delightful treat that will still impress the congregation.

challenges.name: Festive Packaging Predicament
challenges.description: With the Christmas Eve service fast approaching, you realise you've run out of the festive ribbon and boxes needed to package your treats. Rummage through your supplies and around your bakery to find alternative materials that will allow you to present your confections with a touch of holiday magic.

challenges.name: Delicate Decorations Delivery
challenges.description: The delicate chocolate decorations you've crafted for the church treats are almost too pretty to eat! Now you need to find a way to safely transport them from your bakery to St. Bartholomew's without any of them breaking or melting.

challenges.name: Gingerbread House Rescue
challenges.description: Just as you're putting the finishing touches on your magnificent gingerbread house, a sudden cold snap hits Applebottom. The drop in temperature is making the icing crack and the gingerbread walls separate. You'll need to find a way to stabilise the structure before it's time to present it at the church.

shopText:
###Off to the market

Stepping into 'Thistledown Treasures' to acquire your morning provisions, you absent-mindedly thumb the horoscope column.<|rumor|>Today you can afford **<|count|>** items.
rumors: Oven's temper, toffee's tenacity, scone's density, pipes' symphony, and Gingersnap's curiosity will test your ingenuity and resourcefulness today.
Scorching relics, scarlet stains, vanished vessels, purloined pastries, and a dowager's ire - navigate these trials with grace and guile.
Ovens, allergies, and mishaps may arise, but with quick thinking and resourcefulness, even storms and collapses can't spoil the day.
Celestial alignment foretells transformative journeys, creative solutions, and delicate balances. Beware of crumbling foundations; ingenuity shall be your guiding star.

Matches.text: You strike a match and hold it to the opening of the gas pipe leading into the oven. After a few attempts, the gas ignites with a whoosh and the oven roars to life, ready to bake.

Egg whisk.text: You jam the egg whisk into the oven's pilot light opening and whirl it about vigorously, but succeed only in getting it hopelessly stuck.

Wrench.text: You use the wrench to turn the gas valve, allowing the oven to ignite. With a satisfying whoosh, the oven roars to life, ready to bake your delectable creations.

Icing sugar.text: You attempt to sprinkle icing sugar into the oven's pilot light, hoping the fine powder will ignite, but it simply settles in a sad, sweet heap at the bottom of the oven.

Tongs.text: You attempt to use the tongs to reach deep into the oven and light the pilot light, but they prove too short and unwieldy for the task, leaving you slightly singed.

Pastry brush.text: You vigorously brush the inside of the oven with the pastry brush, hoping to dislodge any debris that might be preventing ignition, but the bristles merely flake away, leaving your oven unlit and your brush in tatters.

Wooden spoon.text: You jam the wooden spoon into the oven's gas valve and wiggle it vigorously, but only succeed in snapping the spoon's handle clean off.

Darning needle.text: You jab the darning needle into the gas jet, hoping to clear any blockage, but succeed only in getting the needle stuck fast. Yanking it back out, you realise the needle is now bent out of shape.

Plunger.text: You jam the plunger into the oven's gas pipe and pump vigorously, but succeed only in dislodging a chunk of soot which shoots out and covers you head to toe in black grime.

Rolling pin.text: You jam the rolling pin into the oven's opening and attempt to force the knob to turn, but it snaps off in your hand, leaving the oven just as cold and lifeless as before.

Screwdriver.text: You use the screwdriver to remove the oven's access panel, exposing the ignition mechanism. After a bit of tinkering, you manage to get the pilot light to catch and the oven roars to life.

Vinegar.text: You pour the vinegar into the oven's pilot light opening, hoping the strong smell will somehow encourage it to ignite, but this only leaves you with a pungent oven and a puddle of vinegar to mop up.

Butter.text: You attempt to grease the oven's hinges and knobs with butter, hoping it will help them turn more smoothly. Unfortunately, the butter just makes everything slippery and even harder to operate.

Hammer.text: You give the oven a few sharp raps with the hammer, and to your surprise, it sputters to life with a whoosh of gas and flame.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to use the crochet hook to pick the ancient oven's lock, but the tiny hook proves far too flimsy and snaps off inside the mechanism, jamming it even worse.

Potato masher.text: You jam the potato masher into the oven's gas inlet, hoping to dislodge any blockage, but succeed only in getting the implement firmly stuck.

Tweezers.text: You carefully prise open the oven's control panel with your tweezers and discover a disconnected wire, which you gingerly reconnect, allowing the oven to roar to life just as your first customers enter the shop.

Jam spoon.text: You jab the jam spoon into the oven's pilot light opening and wiggle it about, hoping to dislodge any blockage, but succeed only in getting the spoon stuck fast.

Pliers.text: You jam the pliers into the oven's innards and fiddle with the mechanism until - success! - the pilot light catches and the oven roars to life.

Butter knife.text: You jam the butter knife into the oven's ignition switch and wiggle it about, but succeed only in getting the knife stuck fast.

Matches.text: You strike a match and hold the flame near the toffee, hoping to melt it, but the toffee catches fire and scorches the inside of the till, filling the bakery with an acrid smell of burnt sugar.

Egg whisk.text: You jam the egg whisk into the till and furiously crank the handle, but the toffee proves too stubborn and the whisk's wires quickly become hopelessly gummed up.

Wrench.text: You jam the sturdy wrench into the till and pry it open, then use the wrench to scrape out the gooey toffee wad.

Icing sugar.text: You sprinkle a generous amount of icing sugar over the toffees, hoping the fine powder will absorb the stickiness, but it only creates a gummy paste that further clogs the mechanism.

Tongs.text: You carefully insert the tongs into the till, gripping the sticky toffee wad and slowly extracting it from the mechanism.

Pastry brush.text: You try to poke the toffee wad out with the bristles of your pastry brush, but the gooey mess just clings stubbornly to the brush, pulling sticky strands everywhere and making an even bigger mess.

Wooden spoon.text: You jam the wooden spoon into the till, attempting to pry out the sticky toffees, but succeed only in wedging the spoon in alongside the sweets, gumming up the mechanism even worse than before.

Darning needle.text: You carefully thread the darning needle and use it to pick apart the sticky toffee, bit by bit, until you're able to pry the till open at last.

Plunger.text: You jam the plunger into the till, but the toffee proves too stubborn and the rubber cup pops right off the wooden handle, leaving you holding a useless stick.

Rolling pin.text: You jam the rolling pin into the till and attempt to lever out the toffees, but they're wedged in too tightly. The rolling pin becomes hopelessly stuck, glued to the mess by the warm, gooey sweets.

Screwdriver.text: You carefully use the screwdriver to pry open the till and scrape out the gummy toffee residue, freeing up the mechanism.

Vinegar.text: You pour the vinegar into the till, hoping the acid will break down the sticky toffee, but it only makes the gooey mess worse, and now there's a strong odour of vinegar in your shop.

Butter.text: You smear butter all over the sticky toffees in an attempt to grease them out, but the butter just mixes with the caramel, making an even gooier mess.

Hammer.text: You bang the till repeatedly with the hammer, but the toffees remain stubbornly wedged in place. In your frustration, you accidentally smash the till's display, sending shards of plastic and bits of circuitry flying.

Crochet hook.text: You carefully insert the crochet hook into the till's mechanism and use the hooked end to gently pull out the gooey toffees, successfully dislodging them without damaging the delicate inner workings.

Potato masher.text: You jam the potato masher into the till, attempting to dislodge the toffees, but they prove too gooey and the masher becomes hopelessly stuck.

Tweezers.text: You carefully insert the tweezers into the till, grasp the toffees, and gently work them free from the mechanism.

Jam spoon.text: You jam the spoon into the till, trying to pry out the toffee, but you only succeed in wedging the utensil firmly into the sticky mess. Now you have a spoon stuck in your till as well as the toffees!

Pliers.text: You carefully insert the tip of the pliers into the till, grasp the sticky toffee wad, and with a few firm tugs, manage to yank the gooey obstruction free.

Butter knife.text: You jam the butter knife into the till, attempting to prise the toffee out, but you only succeed in wedging the sticky sweet even more firmly into the mechanism.

Bent darning needle.text: You carefully insert the bent darning needle into the till's mechanism, using it to prise the toffees free from the gears. After a few minutes of delicate work, you manage to extract the sticky mess and the till pops open with a cheerful ding!

Matches.text: You strike a match and hold the flame under a scone, hoping to soften it, but the scone catches fire and burns to a crisp, setting off the smoke alarm and causing Miss Tilly to flee in alarm.

Egg whisk.text: You frantically whisk the scones, as if beating them into submission, but they remain steadfastly rock-like, and now they're covered in scratches from your vigorous whisking.

Wrench.text: You attempt to soften the scones by pounding them with the wrench, but you only succeed in reducing them to an unappetising pile of crumbs.

Icing sugar.text: You sift the icing sugar generously over the rock-hard scones, creating a delightfully snowy effect that softens their appearance, if not their texture. Miss Tilly is charmed by the festive presentation and politely nibbles away, none the wiser about your baking mishap.

Tongs.text: You deftly use the tongs to break the rock-hard scones into smaller, more manageable pieces, then pop them back in the oven to soften up just in time for Miss Tilly's arrival.

Pastry brush.text: You dip the pastry brush in warm water and gently brush the scones, the moisture softening the crust just enough to make them palatable when Miss Tilly bites in.

Wooden spoon.text: You frantically stir the rock-hard scones with the wooden spoon, but it snaps clean in half under the strain, leaving you with a splintered mess and still-inedible baked goods.

Darning needle.text: You frantically jab the scones with the darning needle, creating dozens of tiny holes in a misguided attempt to make them seem fluffier, but they remain rock-hard and now look like they've been attacked by a miniature porcupine.

Plunger.text: You attempt to pummel the rock-hard scones into submission with the plunger, but you only succeed in splattering crumbs across your kitchen and breaking the plunger's wooden handle in half.

Rolling pin.text: You give the scones a few firm whacks with the rolling pin, crumbling their rock-hard exteriors into a more crumbly, shortbread-like texture that's surprisingly appealing with some jam and cream.

Screwdriver.text: You attempt to chisel away at the rock-hard scones with the screwdriver, but only succeed in scratching your best china and embedding metal shavings in the impenetrable pastries.

Vinegar.text: You pour the entire bottle of vinegar over the rock-hard scones, hoping the acidity will soften them, but they remain inedible and now reek of vinegar.

Butter.text: You slather the rock-hard scones with a generous layer of butter, then pop them back in the oven for a few minutes. The heat melts the butter into the scones, miraculously softening them to an edible texture just as Miss Tilly arrives for elevenses.

Hammer.text: You take the hammer and give the scones a few hefty whacks, but they shatter into a thousand crumbs, leaving you with an even bigger mess to clean up before Miss Tilly arrives.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to use the crochet hook to poke holes in the scones, hoping to aerate them, but the hook bends and snaps under the pressure of the rock-hard pastries.

Potato masher.text: You place the hard scones on a chopping board and mash them into crumbs with the potato masher. You mix the crumbs with butter, sugar, and a touch of milk, press the mixture into a baking tin, and pop it in the oven for a few minutes until you have a lovely batch of scone-based flapjacks to serve Miss Tilly with her tea.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to use the tweezers to pick up each scone and dunk it in tea to soften it up, but the rock-hard scones resist even the mighty tweezers' grip, and you end up with nothing but a few sad crumbs.

Jam spoon.text: You scoop a generous dollop of jam onto each scone, the sweet stickiness softening the rock-hard lumps into something halfway edible, just as Miss Tilly arrives for elevenses.

Pliers.text: You attempt to use the pliers to forcibly pry apart the rock-hard scones, but they crumble into an unappetising mess of jagged crumbs.

Butter knife.text: You deftly wield the butter knife, scraping the burnt bits off the scones and slathering them with generous pats of butter and dollops of jam, transforming them into a delightfully decadent treat that leaves Miss Tilly none the wiser.

Bent darning needle.text: You jab the bent darning needle into a scone, but it's so rock-hard that the needle snaps clean in two!

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You frantically paint the rock-hard scones with toffee from your pastry brush, but the sticky toffee glues your teeth together and Miss Tilly grimaces at the cloying sweetness.

Matches.text: You light a match and hold it up to the pipes, hoping to locate the source of the banging. Unfortunately, the sudden burst of water from a cracked joint extinguishes the match and drenches your hand.

Egg whisk.text: You grab your egg whisk and thrust it into the wall, attempting to bash the pipes into submission, but the thin wires merely bend and snap against the sturdy plumbing.

Wrench.text: You grab your trusty wrench and tighten the loose pipe coupling behind the wall, silencing the disruptive banging noise from the old plumbing.

Icing sugar.text: You frantically pour the entire bag of icing sugar down the drain, hoping the fine powder will somehow soak up the excess water and muffle the noise. Alas, the cacophony continues unabated, and now you're left with a sticky, syrupy mess clogging your pipes.

Tongs.text: You grab the tongs and attempt to reach the noisy pipe through a gap in the wall, but the tongs are too short and unwieldy to manoeuvre effectively in the tight space.

Pastry brush.text: You vigorously scrub the pipes with the pastry brush, but the bristles are far too soft to have any effect on the clanging racket. The noise continues unabated, and you fear the neighbours will be pounding on the bakery door at any moment to complain.

Wooden spoon.text: You probe the plumbing with the wooden spoon, but the clanging only grows louder, and the spoon gets wedged in the pipes.

Darning needle.text: You jam the darning needle into a crack in the wall, hoping to pierce the noisy pipe, but it's far too flimsy and bends uselessly against the plaster.

Plunger.text: You fetch your plunger from the broom cupboard and get to work on the noisy pipes, plunging vigorously until the racket finally subsides.

Rolling pin.text: You bang on the pipes with your rolling pin, hoping to dislodge whatever is causing the racket, but the din only grows louder and more frantic.

Screwdriver.text: You grab your trusty screwdriver and carefully remove the access panel to the bakery's old plumbing. After tightening a few loose pipe fittings, the banging noise subsides, allowing you and your neighbours to enjoy a peaceful morning once again.

Vinegar.text: You pour the vinegar down the drain, hoping the acetic acid will dissolve any blockages, but the loud banging continues unabated.

Butter.text: You retrieve a stick of butter from the larder and rub it vigorously on the noisy pipe, hoping to lubricate the clanking mechanism, but the warmth from your hands quickly melts the butter, leaving a greasy mess on the floor and the din undiminished.

Hammer.text: You grab your trusty hammer and trace the racket to a loose pipe behind the wall. With a few precise whacks, you secure the pipe and the noise abruptly ceases.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to fish the crochet hook through a gap in the wall to snag the noisy pipe, but it gets hopelessly snagged on something inside and you can't pull it back out.

Potato masher.text: You grab your potato masher and start banging it against the walls, hoping to dislodge whatever is causing the racket in the plumbing. The noise only seems to get louder and more frantic, and you realise the potato masher is far too flimsy to solve this problem.

Tweezers.text: You deftly reach into the wall cavity with your tweezers and pinch the offending pipe, stilling its vibrations and silencing the racket before the neighbours are roused from their slumber.

Jam spoon.text: You jam the spoon handle into a gap in the wall near the source of the noise and wiggle it about, but this only makes the racket worse.

Pliers.text: You grab your pliers and pry open the wall panel to access the rattling pipes. With a few deft twists of the pliers, you tighten the loose joints until the cacophony subsides, ensuring a peaceful morning for you and your neighbours.

Butter knife.text: You jam the butter knife into a gap in the wall, hoping to pry loose the noisy pipe, but the knife handle snaps off, leaving the blade wedged in the plaster.

Bent darning needle.text: You attempt to probe the noisy pipes with the bent darning needle, but it's far too flimsy and short to reach the problem. Frustrated, you toss the needle aside and it disappears into a dusty corner, leaving you no closer to silencing the racket.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to muffle the banging by wedging the toffee-covered pastry brush between the pipes, but the sticky toffee melts from the heat and drips onto the floor, leaving you with a bigger mess to clean up.

Matches.text: You strike a match and hold it near the mouse hole, hoping the light and smoke will coax Gingersnap out, but she just hisses and retreats further into the wall.

Egg whisk.text: You poke the handle of the egg whisk into the gap in the wall, but it's far too short to reach Gingersnap. The whisk's wires get hopelessly tangled in the fibreglass insulation.

Wrench.text: You attempt to poke the wrench through a gap in the wall to coax out Gingersnap, but it's far too bulky and unwieldy to reach the trapped kitten.

Icing sugar.text: You sprinkle icing sugar on the floor near the wall, hoping the sweet scent will lure Gingersnap out, but the powdery substance just gets lost in the cracks and crevices.

Tongs.text: You slide the tongs into the gap in the wall, but they're far too short to reach Gingersnap. The metal clangs noisily against the wall, further frightening the poor trapped kitten.

Pastry brush.text: You attempt to lure Gingersnap out with the pastry brush, but the bristles are too soft to reach her through the narrow gap. The brush gets wedged in the wall, just out of your grasp.

Wooden spoon.text: You attempt to lure Gingersnap out by poking the wooden spoon into the hole, but she just bats at it playfully, pushing it further out of reach.

Darning needle.text: You thread the slim darning needle with a length of string, tie a small jingle bell to the end, and dangle it enticingly through a gap in the wall. Soon enough, Gingersnap's little paws bat at the string and she emerges, following it like a feline pied piper.

Plunger.text: You attempt to manoeuvre the stiff rubber cup of the plunger into the wall cavity, but it's far too wide and unwieldy to fit through the narrow gap. The harsh scraping noises you make only frighten poor Gingersnap, causing her to retreat deeper into the wall.

Rolling pin.text: You attempt to shove the rolling pin into the hole in the wall, but it's far too thick to fit. Gingersnap's meows sound more distressed at the loud banging noise.

Screwdriver.text: You gently slide the screwdriver into the hole, poking and prodding to get Gingersnap's attention. After a few moments of teasing, she pounces on the end of the screwdriver and you're able to carefully pull her out to safety.

Vinegar.text: You pour the vinegar into the hole in the wall, hoping the pungent smell will drive Gingersnap out, but it only makes her sneeze and retreat further into the wall.

Butter.text: You attempt to spread butter on the wall to lubricate Gingersnap's exit route, but the butter is too soft and simply smears ineffectually.

Hammer.text: You attempt to hammer a hole in the wall to rescue Gingersnap, but the loud banging only frightens her further into the walls. The hammer proves far too blunt to delicately coax out a skittish kitten.

Crochet hook.text: You carefully thread the crochet hook into the small gap in the wall and gently prod until you feel Gingersnap's fur. After a few gentle tugs and encouragement, she emerges unscathed, dusty but purring.

Potato masher.text: You attempt to use the potato masher to reach through the wall and coax Gingersnap out, but the holes in the masher head are too large - the kitten completely ignores it and continues to meow pitifully.

Tweezers.text: You carefully insert the tweezers into the small gap in the wall and gently nudge Gingersnap, guiding her back to the opening where you can scoop her up to safety.

Jam spoon.text: You attempt to lure Gingersnap out with the jam spoon, but the handle is too short and the spoon bowl too wide to fit between the wall boards.

Pliers.text: You carefully dismantle the pliers, using the two slim metal arms to poke through a gap in the wall and gently nudge Gingersnap towards the opening. With some patient coaxing, she emerges unscathed, if a bit dusty.

Butter knife.text: You carefully slide the thin butter knife into the gap between the wall and skirting board. After a few moments of gentle coaxing, Gingersnap emerges unscathed, if a bit dusty.

Bent darning needle.text: You carefully thread the bent darning needle with a length of string and poke it through a gap in the wall, wiggling it enticingly until Gingersnap bats at it playfully and follows it back out to safety.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to lure Gingersnap out with the toffee-covered pastry brush, but the sticky toffee only picks up dust and debris as you poke it into the wall cavity, making quite a mess.

Matches.text: You strike a match and hold it near the oven's door, hoping to spot the hot spots, but the flickering flame provides little illumination. Frustrated, you toss the spent match aside, no closer to solving the mystery of Lady Beatrice's cantankerous cooker.

Egg whisk.text: You frantically whisk the air inside the oven, hoping to even out the temperature, but the whisk merely clangs against the hot metal surfaces, warping the delicate wires.

Wrench.text: With a few deft twists of your trusty wrench, you adjust the oven's gas valves and realign the heat diffuser, transforming the cantankerous appliance into a reliable baking ally.

Icing sugar.text: You sprinkle icing sugar over the top of your cake before placing it in Lady Beatrice's cantankerous oven, hoping the extra sweetness will distract from any potential baking mishaps. Unfortunately, the sugar caramelises and burns, leaving an acrid smell and a blackened crust that even the most forgiving guest would struggle to enjoy.

Tongs.text: You carefully adjust the oven racks with your trusty tongs, creating an even heat distribution that allows your scones to bake to a perfect golden brown, much to Lady Beatrice's delight.

Pastry brush.text: You meticulously brush egg wash onto the surface of your puff pastry before baking, achieving a perfectly glossy, golden-brown finish that evenly crisps despite the oven's quirks.

Wooden spoon.text: You discover that the wooden spoon is the perfect tool for stirring the batter and scraping the sides of the mixing bowl, ensuring a smooth and even consistency before pouring it into the finicky oven.

Darning needle.text: You attempt to regulate the oven's temperature by jabbing the darning needle into various spots, hoping to create makeshift vents. Unfortunately, the needle becomes hopelessly stuck in the oven's interior, and the erratic heat warps the slender tool, rendering it useless.

Plunger.text: You attempt to use the plunger to regulate the oven's airflow, but only succeed in getting the rubber cup stuck in the vent, filling the kitchen with smoke.

Rolling pin.text: You use the rolling pin to firmly thwack the side of the oven whenever it starts to overheat, skilfully regulating the temperature to ensure an even bake for Lady Beatrice's scones.

Screwdriver.text: You carefully disassemble the oven's heating elements with your trusty screwdriver, meticulously cleaning each component. After reassembling everything and making a few strategic adjustments, the antique oven now bakes evenly, producing perfectly browned treats that delight Lady Beatrice and her guests.

Vinegar.text: You pour vinegar into the antique oven, hoping the acidity will clean out the hot spots, but the caustic liquid only further corrodes the already temperamental relic, leaving you with an even more uneven baking surface.

Butter.text: You slather the interior of the cantankerous oven with a generous layer of butter, which not only helps to even out the heat distribution but also imparts a delightful richness to your baked goods, much to the delight of Lady Beatrice and her guests.

Hammer.text: You raise the hammer high and bring it down with a mighty swing, hoping to give the cantankerous oven a good whack to set it straight, but instead, the hammer's head flies off and shatters the oven's glass door, leaving you with a useless stick and an even more useless oven.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to clear the oven's hot spots by poking at them with your crochet hook, but the hook gets stuck and melts, filling the oven with acrid smoke and ruining your latest batch of scones.

Potato masher.text: You jam the potato masher into the oven's vents, hoping to regulate the heat flow, but it quickly melts into a puddle of plastic goo, filling the kitchen with an acrid stench.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to use the tweezers to remove a burnt scone that's become wedged in the back of the oven, but the tweezers prove too flimsy to dislodge the stubborn pastry.

Jam spoon.text: You prod the jam spoon into various nooks and crannies of the cantankerous oven, but it's far too small to accurately gauge the temperature, and you end up with unevenly baked scones and a sticky, jam-coated spoon.

Pliers.text: Using the pliers, you carefully bend and adjust the metal baffles inside Lady Beatrice's antique oven, redirecting the heat to eliminate hot spots and ensure even baking.

Butter knife.text: You attempt to regulate the oven's temperature by wedging the butter knife between the door and the frame, but it quickly slips out and clatters to the floor, leaving you with an unevenly baked mess.

Butter dish.text: You place the butter dish inside the antique oven, hoping the even heat distribution from the ceramic will regulate the temperature, but the dish shatters, sending shards of pottery and splatters of melted butter all over the interior.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You attempt to fan the flames with your embroidered handkerchief, but the delicate fabric catches fire and disintegrates into ash, leaving the oven as temperamental as ever.

Sponge.text: You dampen the sponge and use it to carefully map out the hot spots in Lady Beatrice's antique oven, making note of the temperature variations so you can adjust your bakes accordingly.

Mirror.text: You attempt to angle the mirror to reflect heat more evenly in the oven, but the glass shatters from the intense temperature, leaving sharp shards scattered among Lady Beatrice's beloved scones.

Silver platter.text: You place the silver platter in the oven, hoping it will conduct heat more evenly, but it warps and tarnishes under the intense temperature, filling the kitchen with an acrid smell.

Lace doily.text: You drape the delicate lace doily over the antique oven's vent, hoping to diffuse the heat, but the doily instantly catches fire and burns to a crisp, filling the kitchen with smoke.

Thermometer.text: You carefully place your trusted oven thermometer in various spots within Lady Beatrice's antique oven, methodically testing and adjusting the temperature until you achieve an even, consistent heat throughout the chamber.

Towel.text: You dampen the towel and drape it over the hot spots in the oven, allowing your delicate pastries to bake evenly to a perfect golden brown, much to Lady Beatrice's delight.

Flowers.text: You arrange a colourful bouquet of flowers in the oven, hoping their beauty will soothe the cantankerous appliance's temper, but the blossoms quickly wither and char, filling the kitchen with acrid smoke.

Tray.text: You place the tray in the antique oven, carefully rotating it at regular intervals to ensure even baking despite the oven's quirky hot spots. Your attentive tray management results in a batch of perfectly browned scones that delight Lady Beatrice and her guests.

Oven gloves.text: With your trusty oven gloves, you confidently adjust the oven racks and rotate the baking trays at precisely timed intervals, ensuring an even bake despite the oven's quirks.

Apron.text: You drape your trusty apron over the oven door, creating an insulating barrier that helps to regulate the heat and minimise hot spots, resulting in evenly baked goods that impress Lady Beatrice's guests.

Dog treats.text: You place a handful of dog treats on the baking tray and slide them into the antique oven, hoping the aroma will somehow appease the temperamental appliance, but the treats quickly burn to a crisp, filling the kitchen with an acrid smoke.

Ribbon.text: You tie a length of ribbon to the oven door handle, hoping it will act as a reminder to check your bakes, but the ribbon catches fire and fills the kitchen with an acrid smell of burning silk.

Bent darning needle.text: You attempt to adjust the oven's temperature by poking at the thermostat with the bent darning needle, but succeed only in snapping the needle's tip off inside the mechanism, rendering the oven even more unreliable.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to clean the antique oven's interior with the toffee-covered pastry brush, but the toffee melts in the heat, leaving a sticky mess that only worsens the oven's uneven baking.

Matches.text: You strike a match and attempt to burn away the jam stain, but succeed only in setting your apron alight. After frantically patting out the flames, you're left with a charred hole in addition to the stain.

Egg whisk.text: You frantically whisk at the jam stain with the egg whisk, but only succeed in spreading the sticky mess around and working it deeper into the fabric.

Wrench.text: You grab your trusty wrench and attempt to pry the stubborn jam stain off your apron, but only succeed in tearing a sizable hole in the fabric.

Icing sugar.text: You hastily dust a thick layer of icing sugar over the offending raspberry jam stain, successfully concealing it beneath a pleasing snowy white coating.

Tongs.text: You grasp the tongs and attempt to pinch the jam stain, but the tongs are too wide and unwieldy to get a grip on the fabric, and you end up smearing the stain further.

Pastry brush.text: You frantically brush at the stubborn raspberry jam stain with the pastry brush, but the delicate bristles only succeed in spreading the sticky mess around, making the stain even more noticeable against the crisp white fabric.

Wooden spoon.text: You desperately attempt to scrape off the sticky raspberry jam with the wooden spoon, but your frantic motions only succeed in spreading the stain further and snapping the spoon in half.

Darning needle.text: You quickly unpick a few stitches from the hem of your apron, then deftly sew a strategically placed patch over the offending stain.

Plunger.text: You frantically grab the plunger and attempt to use the rubber cup to scrub the jam stain out of your apron, but you only succeed in smearing the sticky mess around and adding a few extra wrinkles to the fabric.

Rolling pin.text: You frantically roll the sticky dough over the jam stain, hoping to lift it off, but you only succeed in spreading the stain and covering the rolling pin in goo.

Screwdriver.text: You desperately attempt to scrape the jam off your apron with the screwdriver, but you only succeed in spreading the sticky mess around and tearing holes in the delicate fabric.

Vinegar.text: You dab the vinegar onto a clean cloth and carefully blot at the raspberry jam stain, watching in amazement as it disappears like magic, leaving your apron spotless once more.

Butter.text: You frantically rub the butter into the jam stain, but it only makes the mess worse, leaving a greasy smear intermingled with the sticky raspberry goo.

Hammer.text: You furiously scrub at the stubborn raspberry jam stain with the hammer, but to no avail; the once pristine apron now sports a gaping hole, revealing the equally stained shirt beneath.

Crochet hook.text: You quickly unpin the brooch from your collar and use the sharp end to pick the threads holding the pocket closed on your apron. You slip the crochet hook inside the newly-opened pocket, concealing the jam stain just as the doorbell rings.

Potato masher.text: You frantically mash the potato masher against the raspberry jam stain, but succeed only in grinding the sticky goop deeper into the fabric of your once-pristine apron.

Tweezers.text: You deftly pluck a loose thread from the hem of your apron with the tweezers, then sew the thread over the jam stain in a charming cross-stitch pattern, turning the blemish into a delightful bit of faux embroidery.

Jam spoon.text: You smear the jam spoon around on the apron, making the stain larger and even messier than before.

Pliers.text: You grasp the pliers and attempt to pinch and peel off the sticky jam, but you only succeed in smearing it further into the fabric and staining your hands in the process.

Butter knife.text: You frantically scrape at the stubborn jam stain with the butter knife, but only succeed in spreading the sticky goo further across the once-pristine fabric.

Butter dish.text: You smear butter all over the jam stain, hoping it will help lift it out, but the greasy butter just makes the stain worse and your apron even messier.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You hastily embroider a floral pattern over the jam stain with the handkerchief, stitching it onto the apron to conceal the mishap.

Sponge.text: You quickly grab the sponge and dab at the jam stain, working it gently until the sticky residue is lifted away and your apron is spotless once more.

Mirror.text: You hold up the mirror to assess the damage. With a sigh of relief, you realise the stain is low enough that you can tuck the bottom of the apron up and out of sight, securing it with a safety pin.

Silver platter.text: You turn the silver platter over and use its polished surface as a makeshift mirror, carefully adjusting your apron so that the jam stain is artfully concealed by a well-placed fold.

Lace doily.text: You hastily pin the lace doily to the front of your apron, artfully arranging it to conceal the unsightly jam stain. The delicate white lace blends seamlessly with the apron, creating a charming and elegant appearance that is sure to impress Lady Beatrice and the other guests.

Thermometer.text: You frantically dab at the raspberry jam stain with the thermometer, but it only succeeds in smearing the sticky mess around, making the stain even worse.

Towel.text: You quickly grab a towel and dab at the jam stain, managing to clean most of it off your apron before the guests arrive.

Flowers.text: You hastily pluck a large chrysanthemum from the bouquet on the kitchen table and tuck it jauntily into the bow of your apron, perfectly concealing the garish red stain.

Tray.text: You use the tray to conceal the stain as you greet your guests, holding it strategically in front of your apron until you can slip away and change into a clean one.

Oven gloves.text: You quickly slip the oven gloves over your hands and fold your arms across your chest, effectively concealing the unsightly jam stain on your apron just as Lady Beatrice enters the room.

Apron.text: You quickly take off your apron and turn it inside out, concealing the jam stain. Crisis averted!

Dog treats.text: You rub the dog treats on the sticky jam stain, but this only makes the mess worse, adding crumbs and a meaty odour to the disaster.

Ribbon.text: You quickly untie the ribbon from your hair and use it to fashion a makeshift sash to cover the unsightly jam stain on your apron.

Bent darning needle.text: You quickly thread the needle with white thread and deftly darn over the raspberry stain, blending it seamlessly into the pattern of the apron.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You frantically dab at the jam stain with the toffee-covered pastry brush, but the sticky toffee only makes the mess worse, leaving your apron covered in gooey streaks of pink and brown.

Matches.text: You attempt to use the matches to set the tablecloth ablaze, hoping the chaos will distract from the missing platter. However, you quickly extinguish the small fire, realising this plan would only make matters worse.

Egg whisk.text: You frantically whisk the air with the egg whisk, as if trying to conjure the missing platter out of thin air, but to no avail. The whisk proves useless for locating the lost heirloom.

Wrench.text: You attempt to pry open every drawer and cabinet in the kitchen with the wrench, hoping to uncover the missing platter, but succeed only in damaging the antique furniture.

Icing sugar.text: You liberally dust the area where the platter was last seen with icing sugar, hoping to reveal footprints or other clues, but succeed only in making a powdery mess.

Tongs.text: You attempt to use the tongs to search for the missing platter in hard-to-reach places, but they prove too unwieldy for the task and end up knocking over a vase, causing a loud crash that startles the guests.

Pastry brush.text: You attempt to use the pastry brush to dust for fingerprints on the dining room table, hoping to find clues to the whereabouts of the missing platter. However, this only succeeds in spreading icing sugar all over the polished mahogany surface, making an absolute mess.

Wooden spoon.text: You attempt to use the wooden spoon to pry up floorboards and look behind furniture in hopes of finding the missing platter, but to no avail. The spoon is too flimsy to be an effective tool for this task and ends up snapping in half.

Darning needle.text: You attempt to use the darling needle to carve an intricate design into a wooden platter as a replacement, but your hands slip and you end up with a splintery mess.

Plunger.text: You attempt to use the plunger to reach behind furniture and appliances in search of the missing platter, but your efforts only result in knocking over a vase, which shatters on the floor.

Rolling pin.text: You threaten to thwack anyone who doesn't return the platter with your rolling pin, but this overly aggressive approach just makes everyone avoid you.

Screwdriver.text: You attempt to prise open the locked cabinet where the platter is usually stored, but the screwdriver proves too flimsy and the tip snaps off, embedding itself in the aged wood.

Vinegar.text: You douse the kitchen in vinegar, hoping the pungent smell will lure the platter out of hiding, but succeed only in making your eyes water and the lemon tart quite inedible.

Butter.text: You smear butter all over the dining room, hoping it will make the platter appear shinier and easier to spot, but this only results in a greasy mess.

Hammer.text: You vigorously hammer the floor in frustration, sending splinters of wood flying. The noise startles the cat, who darts under a cabinet, but the platter remains stubbornly missing.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to fish the platter out from behind the dresser using the crochet hook, but only succeed in pushing it further out of reach.

Potato masher.text: You tried to use the potato masher to press decorative patterns into the lemon tart as a distraction from the missing platter, but the tart ended up an unappealing, lumpy mess.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to use the tweezers to lift the lemon tart, hoping to serve it without the platter, but the delicate pastry crumbles apart, leaving you with a mess of curd and crumbs.

Jam spoon.text: You attempt to use the jam spoon to scoop up the lemon tart, hoping to serve it without the platter, but the tart crumbles and oozes onto the tablecloth, creating an unappetising mess.

Pliers.text: You attempt to pry the platter out from behind a heavy cabinet using the pliers, but they slip and leave an unsightly scratch across the platter's delicate surface.

Butter knife.text: You attempt to pry up the floorboards with the butter knife, hoping the platter might be hidden beneath, but the knife proves too flimsy and bends out of shape.

Butter dish.text: You carefully balance your lemon tart atop the butter dish, arranging berries and mint leaves around it to create an elegant presentation.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You attempt to polish the antique china platter with your embroidered handkerchief, but the delicate fabric snags on a chip in the platter's edge, causing it to tumble to the floor and shatter into countless pieces.

Sponge.text: You attempt to distract the guests by wiping down the table with the sponge, hoping they won't notice the missing platter. However, the damp sponge leaves unsightly water marks on the antique tablecloth, drawing even more attention to the absence of the centrepiece.

Mirror.text: You attempt to use the mirror to reflect light and search for the missing platter, but in your haste, you accidentally knock over a vase, shattering it and alerting the Wentworths to your fumbled efforts.

Silver platter.text: You transfer the lemon tart to your silver platter, which beautifully displays the dessert. The heirloom china platter remains missing, but the Wentworths are delighted by your elegant solution.

Lace doily.text: You carefully place the delicate lace doily in the centre of the dessert table, creating an elegant display for your prized lemon tart.

Thermometer.text: You attempt to use the thermometer to search for the missing platter, but it proves utterly ineffective at locating ceramics. After a fruitless hour of wandering about with the thermometer in hand, you're no closer to finding the heirloom.

Towel.text: You attempt to wipe down every surface in the kitchen with the towel, hoping the platter will materialise, but to no avail. The towel becomes grimy and tattered from your frantic searching.

Flowers.text: You arrange a lovely bouquet of flowers on the dining table, hoping to distract from the missing platter, but the lemon tart looks sadly out of place amidst the blooms.

Tray.text: You place your lemon tart on a simple serving tray and garnish it with edible flowers from the garden. The tray may not be an antique platter, but it displays your delectable dessert beautifully.

Oven gloves.text: You rummage through the kitchen wearing your oven gloves, but they make your hands too clumsy to properly search the cupboards and drawers for the missing platter.

Apron.text: You frantically search through your apron pockets, but find only crumbs and flour - no trace of the missing platter.

Dog treats.text: You lure the Wentworths' mischievous pup out from under the table with a trail of tasty treats, revealing the missing platter which had been serving as an impromptu dog bed.

Ribbon.text: You attempt to tie the ribbon around the lemon tart to make it look more presentable, but the ribbon is too short and keeps slipping off the pastry.

Bent darning needle.text: You attempted to use the bent darning needle to pick the lock on the cabinet where the platter was stored, but only succeeded in jamming the needle into the keyhole, rendering it unusable.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to sweep the room with the toffee-covered pastry brush, hoping to uncover the missing platter, but succeed only in leaving sticky toffee residue on the furniture and attracting ants.

Matches.text: You strike a match and wave it at the dog, hoping to scare it into dropping the scones, but the hound merely snaps up the flaming match along with the baked goods, leaving you standing there dumbfounded as it races off trailing wisps of smoke.

Egg whisk.text: You grasp your trusty egg whisk and bolt out into the garden, waving it about and hollering at the absconding hound, but the whisk proves a woefully ineffective dog deterrent as the cur vanishes into the shrubbery with your delectable scones.

Wrench.text: You hurl the wrench at the fleeing hound, but your aim is off and it clatters harmlessly against a tree trunk as the dog disappears into the shrubbery with your precious scones.

Icing sugar.text: You quickly grab a handful of icing sugar and dash out into the garden, whistling and calling the dog. As he bounds over to investigate, you toss the sugar into the air, creating a sweet-smelling cloud that distracts him long enough for you to retrieve the currant scones, relatively unscathed.

Tongs.text: You chase after the dog, tongs in hand. Catching up to the mischievous canine, you deftly use the tongs to pluck the scones from its mouth, rescuing the baked goods from a slobbery fate.

Pastry brush.text: You wave the pastry brush in the hound's direction, hoping to distract him, but he gleefully bounds away into the garden, scones still clamped in his slobbery jaws.

Wooden spoon.text: You brandish the wooden spoon and charge after the dog into the garden, but he easily outpaces you and disappears round the corner with the scones still clamped in his mouth.

Darning needle.text: You attempt to sew the scones back together with the darning needle, but only succeed in making a mess of crumbs and currants. The hunting dog gobbles up the crumbled scones before you can salvage them.

Plunger.text: You attempt to use the plunger to retrieve the scones from the dog's mouth, but the dog easily evades your clumsy lunges and dashes off into the garden, leaving you sprawled in the dirt.

Rolling pin.text: You charge out the door brandishing the rolling pin, but the speedy spaniel easily evades your clumsy swings. Panting, you watch the cur disappear into the distance, prize proudly clamped in his slavering chops.

Screwdriver.text: You attempt to offer the dog a trade, holding out the screwdriver and whistling enticingly, but he merely cocks his head quizzically before bounding away with the scones still clenched between his teeth.

Vinegar.text: You uncork the bottle of vinegar and attempt to lure the dog back with the pungent aroma, but the hound merely sneezes in disgust and continues bounding away with your precious scones.

Butter.text: You lure the dog back with the irresistible aroma of fresh butter, then grab the scones from his mouth and quickly wipe off the slobber.

Hammer.text: You hurl the hammer at the fleeing dog, but your aim is off and it sails into the garden pond with a disappointing splash. The dog gleefully continues his romp with your precious scones still clamped in his mouth.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to hook the scones with your crochet hook, but the dog is too quick and the hook too small, and you only manage to snag a bit of the dog's fur as he races off into the distance.

Potato masher.text: You charge into the garden brandishing the potato masher, but the dog easily evades your wild swings and disappears into the hedgerow with the scones, leaving you red-faced and empty-handed.

Tweezers.text: You chase after the dog, tweezers in hand, but fail to extract the scones from his slobbery jaws before he gulps them down whole.

Jam spoon.text: You brandish the jam spoon and give chase, but the dog is too quick and agile; it easily evades your clumsy attempts to recapture the scones with the inadequate utensil.

Pliers.text: You frantically chase after the dog, brandishing your pliers and shouting "Drop it!" The confused hound cocks its head quizzically at the strange, non-edible object in your hand, then bounds away with renewed vigour, currant scones still clamped firmly in its slobbery jaws.

Butter knife.text: You chase after the dog, brandishing the butter knife and shouting, but he's too quick and agile, easily evading your clumsy attempts to corner him with a piece of cutlery.

Butter dish.text: You chase after the scampering hound, brandishing the butter dish threateningly, but in your haste you trip and fall face-first into a flowerbed, crushing the unfortunate pansies.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You wave your embroidered handkerchief at the dog, hoping to distract him, but he merely sniffs it curiously before bounding away with the scones still clamped in his mouth.

Sponge.text: You fling the sponge at the fleeing hound, but it bounces harmlessly off his shaggy coat as he disappears into the shrubbery with your precious scones clenched between his teeth.

Mirror.text: You attempt to use the mirror to distract the dog, hoping the movement of reflected light will catch its eye, but the pooch is too focussed on its ill-gotten gains and pays the mirror no heed as it vanishes into the garden.

Silver platter.text: You grab a silver platter and race out to the garden, whistling to get the dog's attention. When the hound bounds over with the scones still in his mouth, you hold the platter underneath his jaws and command him to drop the pastries, which he does.

Lace doily.text: You frantically wave the lace doily in an attempt to entice the dog back, but he merely cocks his head quizzically before bounding further into the garden with glee, scattering crumbs and currants in his wake.

Thermometer.text: You attempt to wave the thermometer threateningly at the dog to scare it into dropping the scones, but it merely cocks its head quizzically before bounding away, prize firmly clenched in its slobbery jaws.

Towel.text: You whip the towel at the dog's legs, startling it and causing it to drop the scones. You quickly scoop up the only slightly worse for wear pastries and place them back on the tray.

Flowers.text: You desperately wave the flowers at the dog, hoping the floral scent will distract him, but he pays them no heed and bounds away with the scones still clamped in his jaws.

Tray.text: You quickly grab the tray and hold it above your head, luring the dog back with the delectable scent. As he jumps up to snatch the tray, you deftly catch the scones, rescuing them unscathed.

Oven gloves.text: You grab your trusty oven gloves and sprint after the mischievous hound, managing to corner him and retrieve the pilfered pastries before he can wolf them down.

Apron.text: You flap your apron at the dog in a futile attempt to shoo it away, but the hound merely dodges around you and bounds out the door with the scones still clamped in its slobbery jaws.

Dog treats.text: You quickly grab a handful of dog treats from your pocket and call the Earl's dog. He drops the scones and bounds over to you, eagerly gobbling up the proffered treats.

Ribbon.text: You quickly tie the ribbon to a leftover scone, toss it to the hound, and while he's distracted fetching it, you gather up the currant scones he dropped in the garden.

Bent darning needle.text: You attempt to use the bent darning needle to pry the pastries from the dog's mouth, but the needle proves too flimsy and snaps in half, embedding itself painfully in your thumb.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You quickly grab your toffee-covered pastry brush and dash after the mischievous hound. Catching up to him, you wave the sweet-smelling utensil in front of his nose, successfully luring him to drop the scones in favour of the sticky treat.

Matches.text: In a misguided attempt to win back the Dowager Countess's favour, you set her ostentatious hat ablaze, hoping she would be impressed by your daring pyrotechnic display. Unfortunately, her shrieks of horror and the acrid smell of burning ostrich feathers suggest your plan has gone up in smoke, along with any hopes of securing the manor's baking contract.

Egg whisk.text: You vigorously whisk an egg white meringue peace offering, but your enthusiastic beating splatters the Dowager's prize poodle with sticky goo. The countess storms off in an even greater huff, leaving you with an eggy dog and no closer to reconciliation.

Wrench.text: You attempt to fix the Dowager Countess's hat with the wrench, but your clumsy efforts only result in mangling the delicate headpiece beyond recognition. The fuming aristocrat snatches the ruined hat from your hands and storms off, leaving you in disgrace.

Icing sugar.text: You whip up a batch of exquisite icing in the Dowager Countess's favourite shade of lilac, then use it to decorate a peace offering of petit fours which you present with your sincerest apologies.

Tongs.text: You attempt to use the tongs to remove the Dowager Countess's offending hat, but in your haste, you accidentally pinch her nose, causing her to shriek in outrage and storm off in an even greater huff.

Pastry brush.text: You use the pastry brush to dust the Dowager Countess's hat with a light coating of icing sugar, transforming it into a stylish confection that delights her and wins back her patronage.

Wooden spoon.text: You attempt to apologise to the Dowager Countess by presenting her with a wooden spoon, but she scoffs at the bizarre gift and has her footman toss you out on your ear.

Darning needle.text: You attempt to mend the Dowager Countess's hat with the darning needle, but your clumsy efforts only make the tear worse, further infuriating her.

Plunger.text: You attempt to unclog the Dowager Countess's toilet with the plunger as a peace offering, but this only offends her delicate sensibilities further.

Rolling pin.text: You present the Dowager Countess with a peace offering: a delectable batch of scones, perfectly shaped using your trusty rolling pin. Her frosty demeanour thaws as she savours the delightful treat, and your witty repartee soon has her chuckling merrily.

Screwdriver.text: You attempt to use the screwdriver to sabotage the Dowager Countess's motorcar, hoping to gain her favour by then repairing it, but you're caught in the act by the chauffeur and soundly chastised.

Vinegar.text: In a misguided attempt to apologise, you offer the Dowager Countess a bottle of vinegar, claiming it's a rare gourmet variety. She scoffs at the "peasant's condiment" and sweeps off in a cloud of disapproval, leaving you holding the unwanted gift.

Butter.text: You present the Dowager Countess with a peace offering: a batch of your famous butter biscuits, light and flaky and positively swimming in creamy butter. Her frosty demeanour melts away as she savours the rich, indulgent treat.

Hammer.text: You try to use the hammer to repair the Dowager Countess's hat, but your clumsy attempts only manage to put several new dents in the delicate headpiece, making her even more irate.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to patch things up with the Dowager Countess by crocheting her a lovely antimacassar, but your clumsy stitches only worsen her ire.

Potato masher.text: You angrily mash a potato and fling the lumpy results at the Dowager Countess's hat, further infuriating her. The potato-splattered chapeau is swiftly removed by her ladies-in-waiting as she stalks off in a rage.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to use the tweezers to pluck a stray thread from the Dowager Countess's hat, hoping to impress her with your attention to detail, but your trembling hands cause you to accidentally pull the entire hat apart at the seams.

Jam spoon.text: You attempt to placate the Dowager Countess by offering her a spoonful of your finest jam, but she swats the spoon out of your hand in disgust, splattering the preserve across the parlour rug.

Pliers.text: You attempt to fix the Dowager Countess's hat with pliers, but your clumsy efforts only succeed in mangling the delicate millinery beyond repair, deepening her ire.

Butter knife.text: You attempt to butter up the Dowager Countess with the butter knife, but your clumsy flattery only spreads her ire thicker. She huffs off in a cloud of indignation, leaving you feeling like a right numpty.

Butter dish.text: You attempt to smooth things over with the Dowager Countess by presenting her with an elegant silver butter dish as a peace offering. She scoffs at the gift, proclaiming that she's watching her figure and wouldn't dream of indulging in such a fattening spread.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You embroider a sincere apology onto the handkerchief and present it to the Dowager Countess, who is touched by the heartfelt gesture and invites you to tea.

Sponge.text: You present the Dowager Countess with a lovely Victoria sponge cake, but in your nervousness, you trip and smush it right into her hat, making an even bigger mess of things.

Mirror.text: You present the mirror to the Dowager Countess, allowing her to admire her hat from all angles. Her frosty demeanour thaws as she preens, and she magnanimously forgives your earlier faux pas.

Silver platter.text: You place a selection of your finest pastries on the silver platter and present them to the Dowager Countess with your humblest apologies, which she grudgingly accepts.

Lace doily.text: You deftly fashion the lace doily into an elegant fascinator and present it to the Dowager Countess as a peace offering, which she accepts with a gracious nod, mollified by your thoughtful gesture and handiwork.

Thermometer.text: You whip out the thermometer and wave it about, loudly proclaiming that the Dowager Countess must be feverish to think her hat is at all fashionable. The old battle-axe turns an alarming shade of puce and storms off in a tizzy, vowing never to set foot in your bakery again.

Towel.text: You attempt to placate the Dowager Countess by offering her a towel to dab her tears, but she swats it away in disgust, sending it flying into a nearby puddle.

Flowers.text: You present the Dowager Countess with a beautiful bouquet of flowers as an apology, and she is charmed by the thoughtful gesture, her earlier irritation forgotten.

Tray.text: You arrange a selection of your finest pastries on the tray and present them to the Dowager Countess with your humblest apologies, which she graciously accepts.

Oven gloves.text: You attempt to placate the Dowager Countess by offering her your oven gloves as a peace offering, but she scoffs at the gesture, finding it utterly beneath her station.

Apron.text: You embroider a heartfelt apology onto your apron and present it to the Dowager Countess as a peace offering, along with a batch of her favourite scones. Touched by the gesture, she forgives your faux pas.

Dog treats.text: You offer the Dowager Countess a dog treat, hoping to win her over, but she recoils in disgust, exclaiming, "What do you take me for, some common cur?"

Ribbon.text: You deftly fashion the ribbon into an elegant bow and affix it to a peace offering of your most delectable pastries, which you present to the Dowager Countess with your sincerest apologies.

Bent darning needle.text: You attempt to pacify the Dowager Countess by presenting her with the bent darning needle as a thoughtful gift, but she scoffs at the measly offering, further offended by your insinuation that she would engage in such menial labour as darning.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to sweeten the Dowager Countess's disposition by offering her a pastry brush encrusted with toffee, but she recoils in disgust, exclaiming that such a sticky implement is utterly unsuitable for a woman of her refinement.

Matches.text: You light a match and peer into the ancient oven, quickly identifying the faulty thermocouple as the culprit. After cleaning the component and relighting the pilot light, the oven roars back to life, ready for the baking competition.

Egg whisk.text: You attempt to use the egg whisk to stir the oven's inner workings, but it proves far too flimsy and delicate to have any effect on the heavy-duty components.

Wrench.text: You use the wrench to tighten the loose connections and replace the faulty thermocouple, bringing the ancient oven back to life just in time for the baking competition.

Icing sugar.text: You sprinkle icing sugar over the oven's components, hoping the sweet powder will magically fix the problem, but it only gums up the works even more.

Tongs.text: You attempt to pry open the oven door with the tongs, but they prove far too flimsy and bend out of shape, rendering them useless.

Pastry brush.text: You attempt to poke around inside the oven with the pastry brush, but it's far too flimsy to fix anything and the bristles end up covered in soot.

Wooden spoon.text: You jam the wooden spoon into the oven's inner workings and jiggle it about, hoping to dislodge whatever is causing the problem. The spoon gets stuck and snaps in half, leaving you with a useless handle and a stuck bit of wood.

Darning needle.text: You attempt to use the darning needle to repair the frayed wiring inside the oven, but end up getting a painful electric shock that leaves your hand numb for several minutes.

Plunger.text: You try to use the plunger to unclog the oven's exhaust pipe, hoping that will solve the problem, but the plunger's rubber cup melts from the heat, filling the kitchen with acrid smoke.

Rolling pin.text: You attempt to use the rolling pin to whack the oven back into working order, but you only succeed in denting the pin and bruising your pride.

Screwdriver.text: You deftly remove the oven's back panel with your screwdriver and tighten a few loose connections, bringing the appliance back to life just in time for the competition.

Vinegar.text: You pour the vinegar over the oven's grimy heating elements, hoping the acetic acid will dissolve the built-up grime, but the pungent liquid only creates an eye-watering cloud of vinegary steam that sends you stumbling out of the village hall, coughing and spluttering.

Butter.text: You attempt to grease the oven's gears with butter, but the melted butter seeps into the heating element, causing it to short out and fail completely.

Hammer.text: You use the hammer to give the ancient oven a few sharp taps, and to your surprise, it sputters back to life, ready for the baking competition.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to use the crochet hook to fix the oven's wiring, but you only succeed in getting the hook tangled in a mess of cables and melted plastic.

Potato masher.text: You jam the potato masher into the oven's innards and attempt to force the mechanism to turn, but you only succeed in mangling the masher's wire head.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to prise open the oven door with the tweezers, but they are far too small and flimsy to budge the heavy, rusted hinges. Frustrated, you toss the tweezers aside and survey the oven, wondering how on earth you'll get it working in time.

Jam spoon.text: You attempt to pry open the oven door with the jam spoon, but it snaps in half, leaving you with a useless handle and a bit of spoon stuck in the door.

Pliers.text: You use the pliers to carefully adjust the gas valve on the ancient oven, tweaking it until the flame burns steadily once more. The baking competition is saved!

Butter knife.text: You attempt to pry open the oven door with the butter knife, but the flimsy utensil bends and snaps under the strain, leaving you with a broken handle and a still-malfunctioning oven.

Butter dish.text: You attempt to use the butter dish to prop up the oven door, hoping it will help distribute the heat more evenly, but the dish promptly melts into a puddle of ceramic goo.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You frantically wave the embroidered handkerchief at the oven, as if trying to fan the flames of its motivation, but to no avail; the oven remains cold and lifeless.

Sponge.text: You attempt to clean the ancient oven with the sponge, but the grime is so thick and caked-on that the sponge disintegrates into useless crumbs almost immediately.

Mirror.text: You hold the mirror up to the ancient oven, hoping to use the reflection to see what's wrong inside, but the glass immediately cracks from the heat, sending shards flying everywhere.

Silver platter.text: You place the silver platter in the oven, hoping to reflect the heat and get it working again, but the platter quickly tarnishes and warps, leaving you with a blackened, misshapen mess.

Lace doily.text: You attempt to tie the lace doily around the oven's broken handle, but the delicate fabric instantly tears and the oven door falls off completely.

Thermometer.text: You use the thermometer to check the oven's internal temperature, which reveals that the thermostat is miscalibrated. After adjusting it, the oven springs back to life, ready for the competition.

Towel.text: You use the towel to protect your hands from the heat as you reach deep inside the ancient oven, jiggling a loose connection until the pilot light flickers back to life.

Flowers.text: You present the flowers to the ancient oven, but it remains stubbornly unimpressed by your floral tribute. The baking competition looms ever closer as you realise flowers alone won't fix this particular problem.

Tray.text: You attempt to use the baking tray to prop up the broken oven door, but it's too flimsy and the door falls off completely, clattering to the floor.

Oven gloves.text: You put on your trusty oven gloves and reach into the ancient oven, jiggling the loose wires until the heating element flickers back to life.

Apron.text: You frantically tie your apron around the oven door handle and yank with all your might, but the handle breaks off in your hands, leaving the oven just as broken as before.

Dog treats.text: You attempt to lure the oven out of its stubborn funk by placing a trail of dog treats leading up to it, but the inanimate appliance fails to take the bait.

Ribbon.text: You tie the ribbon around the oven door handle and yank with all your might, but the stubborn door remains firmly closed, and the ribbon snaps in two.

Whisk.text: You attempt to use the whisk to stir the coals in the oven, hoping to reignite the fire, but succeed only in getting the whisk hopelessly stuck in the grate.

Mixing bowls.text: You place the mixing bowls over the hob in a makeshift double boiler, hoping to melt some ingredients to make a rudimentary glue, but the bowls quickly overheat and warp out of shape, rendering them useless.

Piping bag.text: You attempt to fix the oven by piping icing into the various cracks and openings, hoping it will act as a sealant. Unfortunately, the icing melts and burns, leaving you with a smoky, sticky mess.

Measuring cups.text: You attempt to measure the interior dimensions of the oven using your measuring cups, but they're far too small to be of any use. Frustrated, you toss the cups aside, where they clatter noisily across the floor.

Flour.text: You sprinkle flour over the broken oven in a desperate attempt to fix it, but this only makes a bigger mess and wastes precious baking ingredients.

Baking powder.text: You sprinkle baking powder liberally over the broken oven, hoping it will magically spring back to life, but sadly, nothing happens.

Spanner.text: You use the spanner to tighten the loose connections and give the oven's innards a good thump, bringing it spluttering back to life just in time for the first pies to go in.

Eggs.text: You crack the eggs into a bowl and attempt to use the slimy mixture as a lubricant on the oven's stuck mechanical parts, but this only makes things worse by gumming up the works.

Torch.text: You shine your torch into the old oven, quickly identifying a loose connection that you're able to repair, getting the oven working just in time for the competition.

Cooling rack.text: You attempt to wedge the cooling rack under the broken oven door to prop it open, but the flimsy wire rack immediately buckles under the weight and snaps in two.
