Cake stand.text: You attempt to prop up the oven door with the cake stand, but it is far too flimsy and immediately buckles under the weight, clattering to the floor.

Bent darning needle.text: You try to use the bent darning needle to clear out some of the gunk and debris clogging up the ancient oven, but the needle proves far too flimsy and snaps off inside, lodging uselessly in the mess.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to lure the oven back into working order by inserting your toffee-covered pastry brush into its innards, but alas, you only succeed in gumming up the works with sticky toffee.

Lilac icing sugar.text: You sprinkle the lilac icing sugar into the ancient oven, hoping the sweetness will coax it back to life, but the sugar melts into a sticky mess, gumming up the works even more.

Matches.text: You light a match, hoping the flame will somehow make the baked goods safe for Tommy, but it only sets off the smoke alarm and burns your fingers.

Egg whisk.text: You grab your trusty egg whisk and set to work modifying your recipes, substituting egg whites for the nuts to create light, fluffy cakes and biscuits that are just as delicious as the originals.

Wrench.text: You attempt to use the wrench to modify your baking equipment, but the heavy tool damages your prized mixing bowl and makes an awful racket, startling poor Tommy.

Icing sugar.text: You adjust your cake and biscuit recipes, replacing sugar with icing sugar to make them safe for Tommy to enjoy without compromising on taste or texture.

Tongs.text: You attempt to use the tongs to handle the ingredients for Tommy's nut-free treats, but the tongs prove too clumsy and imprecise for the delicate work required.

Pastry brush.text: You use the pastry brush to apply an egg wash glaze to the nut-free treats, giving them a golden sheen that rivals the appearance of your signature bakes.

Wooden spoon.text: You use your trusty wooden spoon to carefully mix together ingredients for delectable nut-free bakes, ensuring that Tommy can safely savour every morsel.

Darning needle.text: You attempt to use the darning needle to poke air holes in the pastries, hoping it will prevent any allergic reactions, but the holes are too small to make a difference and the needle gets stuck in a scone.

Plunger.text: You attempt to use the plunger to mix together a nut-free batter, but the heavy rubber head proves unwieldy and difficult to clean between batches, leaving you worried about potential cross-contamination.

Rolling pin.text: You use your trusty rolling pin to roll out the dough extra thin, allowing you to create more layers in your pastry and achieve a delightfully flaky texture without relying on nuts.

Screwdriver.text: You attempt to use the screwdriver to adjust the oven temperature, hoping it will prevent triggering Tommy's allergy, but you accidentally break the oven's thermostat instead.

Vinegar.text: You pour the vinegar into the cake batter, hoping its acidity will somehow neutralise the nut proteins, but the resulting cake is both potentially deadly and utterly inedible.

Butter.text: You used the butter to create a delectable array of nut-free baked goods, ensuring that Tommy could safely savour every morsel during the judging.

Hammer.text: You attempt to crack the nuts with the hammer to remove the allergens, but you end up pulverising the nuts into a fine powder that permeates the entire kitchen, contaminating all the baked goods and making them unsafe for Tommy to consume.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to crochet a nut-free cake using your crochet hook, but the resulting woolly mess is completely inedible and leaves poor Tommy in tears.

Potato masher.text: You attempt to mash the nuts into a fine paste with the potato masher, hoping to disguise their presence in the baked goods, but the chunks are still clearly visible and pose a serious risk to Tommy's health.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to use the tweezers to meticulously remove any trace of nuts from the baked goods, but it's an exercise in futility given the thorough mixing of ingredients.

Jam spoon.text: You use the jam spoon to stir the batter, but it does nothing to address Tommy's nut allergy, and the spoon gets hopelessly lost in the mixing bowl.

Pliers.text: You attempt to use the pliers to remove the nuts from the baked goods, but end up crushing the delicate pastries into an unappetising mess.

Butter knife.text: You attempt to use the butter knife to modify your award-winning recipes, but it's far too blunt to make the precise alterations needed to accommodate Tommy's allergy.

Butter dish.text: You proudly present Tommy with a plate of biscuits made using your butter dish, but his face falls as he explains that butter is often contaminated with nut proteins during manufacturing.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You attempt to strain the nut-free batter through your embroidered handkerchief, but the mixture is too thick and the handkerchief becomes hopelessly clogged with dough.

Sponge.text: You attempt to bake a nut-free sponge cake for Tommy, but the texture is rubbery and unpleasant, making it unsuitable for the competition.

Mirror.text: You hold the mirror up to Tommy's face, hoping it will somehow protect him from his allergies, but he starts sneezing uncontrollably as soon as he catches a whiff of the nutty confections.

Silver platter.text: You place Tommy's nut-free baked goods on the silver platter, but as you carry it to the judging table, you trip and the treats tumble to the ground, now hopelessly contaminated.

Lace doily.text: You attempt to place the lace doily over the baked goods, hoping it will somehow filter out the allergens, but the delicate material immediately catches fire in the oven, filling the kitchen with smoke and ruining the treats.

Thermometer.text: You attempt to use the thermometer to measure the temperature of each ingredient, hoping this will somehow make the recipe nut-free, but it doesn't prevent cross-contamination or magically remove the allergens from the existing ingredients.

Towel.text: You attempt to wrap the baked goods in a towel to protect them from contamination, but the towel fibres stick to the sticky icing and render the treats inedible.

Flowers.text: You bake a lovely cake and decorate it with edible flowers, but the pollen causes Tommy to have an allergic reaction.

Tray.text: You arrange an assortment of nut-free biscuits and cakes on the tray, ensuring Tommy can safely sample each delectable treat during the judging.

Oven gloves.text: You carefully don your trusty oven gloves and retrieve the freshly-baked, nut-free treats from the oven, ensuring Tommy can safely savour the delightful flavours without any risk of an allergic reaction.

Apron.text: You tie on your apron and get to work, but in your haste to create a nut-free recipe, you accidentally knock over a jar of peanuts, contaminating your entire kitchen and rendering it unsafe for Tommy's consumption.

Dog treats.text: You bake delicious dog treats for Tommy, but his allergy is triggered anyway because you used peanut butter as a binding agent.

Ribbon.text: You attempt to tie a ribbon around the biscuits to make them look more appealing, but the ribbon does nothing to address Tommy's nut allergy.

Whisk.text: You use the whisk to thoroughly mix the ingredients for your nut-free bakes, ensuring an even distribution of flavour throughout each delectable morsel that Tommy can safely enjoy.

Mixing bowls.text: You use your trusty mixing bowls to create delectable nut-free versions of your award-winning bakes, ensuring Tommy can safely savour every morsel without compromising on flavour.

Piping bag.text: You use the piping bag to pipe an intricate decorative pattern on top of the nut-free biscuits, elevating their visual appeal without compromising Tommy's safety.

Measuring cups.text: You carefully measure out the ingredients for your nut-free bakes, ensuring precision to maintain the delicious flavour and texture of your award-winning recipes.

Flour.text: You use the flour to bake a variety of delectable nut-free treats for Tommy, ensuring he can safely participate in judging the competition without missing out on any of the tasty delights.

Baking powder.text: You use the baking powder in place of self-raising flour in your revised scone and cake recipes, ensuring a perfect rise without any nuts.

Spanner.text: You attempt to use the spanner to adjust the oven temperature, hoping it will make the nut-free bakes more delicious. Unfortunately, your tinkering only results in a broken oven and even less appetising treats.

Eggs.text: You whip up a batch of delectable egg-based treats like meringues and sponge cakes, ensuring Tommy can enjoy the competition without any risk of nut contamination.

Torch.text: You hold the torch over the mixing bowl, hoping to melt the chocolate, but you accidentally set the batter ablaze, filling the kitchen with smoke and ruining the nut-free treats for Tommy.

Cooling rack.text: You use the cooling rack to cool batches of delectable nut-free biscuits and cakes, ensuring a scrumptious spread that Tommy can sample safely.

Cake stand.text: You place your cake stand on the table, hoping to arrange Tommy's allergen-free bakes in an attractive display, but the stand's multiple tiers prove too small to accommodate more than a couple of treats.

Bent darning needle.text: You attempt to use the bent darning needle to carefully remove any nuts from the pastries, but your hands are shaky and you accidentally stab yourself, causing you to jerk back and knock over the tray of baked goods.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to use the toffee-covered pastry brush to apply a nut-free glaze to the pastries, but the toffee contamination from the brush triggers Tommy's allergies, disqualifying you from the competition.

Lilac icing sugar.text: The lilac icing sugar adds a pretty colour to the biscuits, but does nothing to replace the ground almonds in the recipe. Tommy has an anaphylactic reaction after just one bite.

Dented Rolling Pin.text: You attempt to use the dented rolling pin to crush the nuts finely enough that they won't trigger Tommy's allergy, but the irregular surface results in an inconsistent texture that still contains dangerous nut fragments.

Matches.text: You strike a match, hoping to light the stove and bake something to tide Miss Pemberton over, but in your haste, you accidentally set fire to her lace curtains.

Egg whisk.text: You use the egg whisk to quickly mix up a new batch of ingredients for Miss Pemberton, ensuring she can still participate in the competition with her signature bakes.

Wrench.text: You attempt to use the wrench to open Miss Pemberton's tightly sealed ingredient jars, but your efforts only succeed in denting the lids and making them impossible to remove by hand.

Icing sugar.text: You sift the icing sugar to remove any lumps, then measure out the precise amount Miss Pemberton needs to complete her baking.

Tongs.text: You attempt to use the tongs to pick up the spilt ingredients from the floor, but they are too small and fiddly to be effective, and you end up making an even bigger mess.

Pastry brush.text: You brandish your trusty pastry brush and set to work, delicately whisking together a fresh batch of ingredients from your own kitchen stores to replace Miss Pemberton's ruined ones, ensuring she can still compete in the baking competition.

Wooden spoon.text: You use the wooden spoon to quickly mix up a fresh batch of ingredients from your own supplies, ensuring Miss Pemberton can still participate in the competition.

Darning needle.text: You attempt to use the darning needle to splice the split ingredients back together, but it's far too small and fiddly for the task. The needle keeps slipping out of your fingers, and you end up pricking yourself painfully several times.

Plunger.text: You attempt to use the plunger to mix up a new batch of ingredients for Miss Pemberton, but the plunger's rubber end imparts an unpleasant rubbery taste to the mixture, rendering it inedible.

Rolling pin.text: You use your rolling pin to quickly and evenly roll out the remaining dough scraps Miss Pemberton has on hand, creating enough passable biscuits for her to enter the competition.

Screwdriver.text: You attempt to use the screwdriver to open the tins of ingredients, but in your haste, you damage the lids beyond repair, rendering the contents useless.

Vinegar.text: You rush to Miss Pemberton's aid with the vinegar, but upon adding it to the mixture, you realise that it reacts disastrously with the baking soda, causing an eruption of foam that ruins the remaining ingredients.

Butter.text: You generously offer your butter to Miss Pemberton, allowing her to complete her baking just in time for the competition.

Hammer.text: You frantically search for a way to crush some wheat into flour using the hammer, but you end up pulverising Miss Pemberton's worktop instead, leaving a splintery mess.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to use the crochet hook to mix the ingredients, but it proves woefully inadequate for the task, leaving you with a lumpy, inedible mess.

Potato masher.text: You attempt to crush some potatoes into a fine powder to substitute for flour, but the starchy mess is far too dense and gluey to be of any use in baking.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to use the tweezers to carefully pick up each individual grain of sugar and flour, but this proves far too time-consuming to be a viable solution.

Jam spoon.text: You attempt to scoop up the spilt ingredients with your jam spoon, but it's far too small to be effective and you end up making an even bigger mess.

Pliers.text: You attempt to use the pliers to open a tin of baking powder as a substitute ingredient, but in your haste, you crush the tin, spilling the contents all over the floor.

Butter knife.text: Wielding the butter knife, you attempt to gather replacement ingredients from the village green, but the unimpressed grocer refuses to accept a butter knife as payment. Dejected, you return to Miss Pemberton empty-handed.

Butter dish.text: You rush over to Miss Pemberton's with your butter dish, only to find that she needs flour, sugar, and eggs - not butter. The butter dish is of no use in this situation.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You attempt to strain the spilled ingredients through your embroidered handkerchief, but the delicate fabric is quickly saturated and the mixture seeps through, making an even bigger mess.

Sponge.text: You attempt to use the sponge to clean up the spilt ingredients, but it quickly becomes saturated and fails to salvage enough for Miss Pemberton's baking.

Mirror.text: You hold up the mirror to Miss Pemberton, hoping it will somehow magically produce the needed ingredients, but alas, it merely reflects her disappointed face and your own sheepish expression.

Silver platter.text: You rush to Miss Pemberton's house with the silver platter, only to discover that it's far too small to carry the amount of ingredients she needs.

Lace doily.text: You attempt to strain Miss Pemberton's spilled ingredients through the delicate lace doily, but the fine powder clogs the holes and the doily tears under the weight, ruining both the ingredients and the doily.

Thermometer.text: You offer Miss Pemberton your thermometer to measure the temperature of her oven, but it's not precise enough for baking and doesn't help her obtain the needed ingredients.

Towel.text: You attempt to mop up the spilled ingredients with the towel, but it quickly becomes saturated and fails to restore the supplies to a usable state.

Flowers.text: You present Miss Pemberton with a bouquet of fresh flowers, hoping to cheer her up, but alas, they do nothing to solve her ingredient shortage.

Tray.text: You rush to the village store with your trusty tray and purchase the required ingredients, delivering them to a grateful Miss Pemberton just in time for the competition.

Oven gloves.text: You attempt to use your oven gloves to scoop up the spilt ingredients, but they are far too clumsy for the delicate task and you end up making an even bigger mess.

Apron.text: You attempt to gather the spilled ingredients into your apron, but the fine flour and sugar slip through the fabric, leaving you with a bigger mess than before.

Dog treats.text: You offer the dog treats to Miss Pemberton, but they're hardly a suitable replacement for the spilt baking ingredients, and she politely declines your well-intentioned but misguided attempt to help.

Ribbon.text: You attempt to tie the ribbon around the spilt ingredients, hoping to magically restore them, but the ribbon merely becomes soiled and sticky, and the ingredients remain unusable.

Whisk.text: You lend Miss Pemberton your whisk, allowing her to combine a new batch of ingredients just in time for the baking competition.

Mixing bowls.text: You lend Miss Pemberton your mixing bowls, allowing her to quickly whip up a new batch of ingredients just in time for the competition.

Piping bag.text: You use the piping bag to carefully transfer the remaining usable ingredients into new bowls, allowing Miss Pemberton to continue her baking unimpeded.

Measuring cups.text: You lend Miss Pemberton your measuring cups, allowing her to carefully portion out ingredients from the village pantry to replace those lost in her mishap.

Flour.text: You generously offer your flour to Miss Pemberton, giving her enough to replace her ruined ingredients. She gratefully accepts and is able to bake her recipe in time for the competition.

Baking powder.text: You generously offer your tin of baking powder to Miss Pemberton, allowing her to whip up a fresh batch of scones just in time for the competition.

Spanner.text: You attempt to use the spanner to gather ingredients, but it proves utterly ineffective at harvesting eggs or milking cows. Frustrated, you toss the spanner aside and continue your search for a more suitable solution.

Eggs.text: You rush to Miss Pemberton's aid with a carton of eggs from your own larder, allowing her to whip up a fresh batch of ingredients just in time for the baking competition.

Torch.text: You shine your torch frantically around Miss Pemberton's kitchen, but the harsh glare only serves to highlight the mess of spilt flour, broken eggs, and scattered utensils, offering no solutions to the ingredient shortage.

Cooling rack.text: You rush to Miss Pemberton's shop with your cooling rack, which you lend to her so she can prepare a fresh batch of ingredients in time for the competition.

Cake stand.text: You rush to Miss Pemberton's aid with your trusty cake stand, but alas, it's far too small to hold the quantity of ingredients she requires for the competition.

Bent darning needle.text: You attempt to use the bent darning needle to splice together the split bags of flour, but the needle is too thin and fragile, breaking off inside one of the bags and contaminating the contents.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to sweep up the spilt ingredients with your toffee-covered pastry brush, but succeed only in making a bigger sticky mess and ruining the brush.

Lilac icing sugar.text: You offer the lilac icing sugar to Miss Pemberton, who gratefully accepts it as a substitute for her ruined ingredients, allowing her to complete her baking just in time for the competition.

Dented Rolling Pin.text: You attempt to gather the spilt ingredients into a pile using the dented rolling pin, but only succeed in spreading the mess around and getting flour and sugar stuck in the pin's crevices.

Edible Flowers.text: You visit Miss Pemberton and offer her your collection of edible flowers to use as a creative garnish for her bakes. She is delighted by the idea and thanks you profusely, promising to credit you if she wins.

Matches.text: You strike a match and carefully light several candles and oil lamps positioned around the competition venue, bathing the room in a warm, comforting glow that allows the bakers to continue their work undeterred.

Egg whisk.text: You frantically whisk the egg mixture, hoping the vigorous motion will somehow restore power to the village, but alas, your arm grows weary and the lights remain stubbornly dark.

Wrench.text: You attempt to use the wrench to pry open the oven door, hoping to utilise the residual heat, but the metal handle snaps off and the oven remains firmly shut.

Icing sugar.text: You sprinkle icing sugar over the unfinished baked goods, hoping the white powder will magically reflect enough light to illuminate the room, but it merely dissolves into the cake batter. The kitchen remains shrouded in darkness, and you sigh in frustration as you blindly grope for a more practical solution.

Tongs.text: You attempt to use the tongs to hold a candle, hoping to illuminate the competition area, but the candle slips from the tongs' grasp and falls onto a tablecloth, setting it alight.

Pastry brush.text: You attempt to use the pastry brush to fan the flames of the wood-burning oven, hoping to generate more heat and light. However, the brush catches fire and you have to quickly extinguish it in a bucket of water, rendering it unusable.

Wooden spoon.text: You frantically wave the wooden spoon around, hoping it will somehow generate electricity, but alas, it remains an ordinary utensil, leaving you in the dark.

Darning needle.text: You attempt to use the darning needle to repair the torn awning over the competition area, hoping to provide some shelter from the storm, but the delicate needle proves too flimsy for the heavy, rain-soaked fabric and snaps in half.

Plunger.text: You attempt to use the plunger to clear out the bakery's chimney, hoping to let in more light and create a makeshift wood-fired oven, but you only succeed in getting the plunger thoroughly stuck.

Rolling pin.text: You attempt to use the rolling pin as a makeshift rolling blackout to block the light from the windows, hoping to conserve the remaining daylight. However, the thunderstorm outside is too dark and gloomy, leaving the room shrouded in shadow despite your efforts.

Screwdriver.text: You attempt to use the screwdriver to pry open the fuse box and rewire it, hoping to restore power, but you end up causing a shower of sparks that singes your eyebrows and leaves the bakery in complete darkness.

Vinegar.text: You pour vinegar over the wood in the oven, hoping the chemical reaction will generate enough heat to bake the pastries, but it merely creates a sharp odour that permeates the entire bakery.

Butter.text: You attempt to use the butter as a makeshift candle by moulding it around a wick, but the butter melts too quickly, creating a greasy mess and failing to provide any useful light.

Hammer.text: You futilely attempt to hammer some nails into a candle, hoping to create a makeshift lantern, but only succeed in smashing the candle to bits and scattering wax across the floor.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to use the crochet hook to pick the lock on the community centre's generator shed, but the delicate hook snaps off in the rusty padlock.

Potato masher.text: You attempt to mash some potatoes by candlelight, hoping to serve mashed potatoes to the competition attendees, but in the dim light you accidentally mash your thumb instead, letting out a yelp of pain.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to use the tweezers to splice some exposed wires, hoping to restore power, but you receive a nasty shock that leaves your hair standing on end.

Jam spoon.text: You wave the jam spoon frantically, trying to catch the other bakers' attention in the darkness, but they can't see your diminutive utensil and continue to stumble about in confusion.

Pliers.text: You attempt to use the pliers to twist together some wires and create a makeshift electrical circuit, but the live wires spark and shock you, causing you to drop the pliers and plunging the room into darkness.

Butter knife.text: Wielding your trusty butter knife, you attempt to pry open the fuse box in hopes of restoring power, but the knife proves woefully inadequate for the task, leaving you fumbling in the dark.

Butter dish.text: You placed the butter dish on the counter, hoping its shiny surface would reflect enough light to illuminate the room, but the feeble glow was far too dim to be of any practical use.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You attempt to fan the flames of the oven with your embroidered handkerchief, but it catches fire and burns to ashes, leaving you in the dark.

Sponge.text: You attempt to use the sponge to soak up some water from the storm to dampen the wood in your oven, hoping to generate steam for baking, but the meagre heat from the dying embers is insufficient to get the sodden sponge to produce enough steam to cook anything.

Mirror.text: You attempt to reflect the sunlight onto your oven with the mirror, but the storm clouds are too thick and the light is too dim to generate any useful heat.

Silver platter.text: You attempt to use the silver platter to reflect the sunlight streaming through the window, directing it towards the oven in hopes of generating enough heat to bake the goods, but the feeble rays provide insufficient warmth to make any difference.

Lace doily.text: You attempt to set the lace doily alight to provide some candlelight, but it burns up in a flash, leaving you in darkness once more.

Thermometer.text: You place the thermometer near the oven to monitor the temperature, ensuring the baked goods are cooked properly despite the power outage. The storm passes, and the competition is a success thanks to your quick thinking!

Towel.text: You attempt to use the towel to fan the flames of the wood-fired oven, but it catches fire and burns to ashes, leaving you with no way to bake the goods.

Flowers.text: You arrange the flowers in a vase and place them near the competition entries, hoping their colourful beauty will distract from the lack of light, but the stormy darkness proves too oppressive and the flowers wilt in the gloom.

Tray.text: You place the tray on the counter, but it's far too small to hold enough candles or lamps to adequately light the large competition marquee. The metal surface reflects the occasional flashes of lightning from outside, but provides no useful illumination of its own.

Oven gloves.text: You slide your trusty oven gloves onto your hands and carefully remove the hot baking trays from the oven, bringing them outside to continue cooking the baked goods over a makeshift campfire.

Apron.text: You attempt to fan the dying flames of the oven with your apron, but the fabric is too heavy and damp from the humid storm air to be effective.

Dog treats.text: You attempt to use the dog treats to lure neighbourhood dogs to power a generator by running on a treadmill, but the dogs simply eat the treats and wander off.

Ribbon.text: You tie the ribbon around a candle, hoping to hang it from the ceiling as a makeshift lamp, but the thin fabric quickly catches fire and burns to ash, leaving you in the dark once more.

Whisk.text: You frantically whisked the cake batter in the dark, hoping the friction would generate enough heat to bake it, but you only ended up with a sore arm and a bowl of goop.

Mixing bowls.text: You frantically mix batter in the bowls, hoping the vigorous activity will generate enough heat to bake the cakes, but they remain stubbornly raw and the village plunges into darkness.

Piping bag.text: You attempt to use the piping bag as a makeshift bellows to fan the flames of the wood-burning oven, but the delicate bag bursts, sending icing splattering everywhere.

Measuring cups.text: You frantically attempt to reflect the beam of your torch off the shiny measuring cups to illuminate the competition area, but the feeble, flickering light is far too dim to be of any practical use.

Flour.text: You attempt to use the flour to create a makeshift wick for an oil lamp, but the flour ignites in a flash, singeing your eyebrows and leaving you in the dark once more.

Baking powder.text: You frantically sprinkle baking powder around the room, hoping it will somehow generate light, but the room remains pitch black.

Spanner.text: You attempt to use the spanner to loosen the pipes and redirect gas to the ovens, but the spanner slips, causing a leak that fills the kitchen with the stench of rotten eggs.

Eggs.text: You cracked the eggs into a bowl, hoping to whisk them vigorously enough to generate heat and light, but you only ended up with a gooey, inedible mess and no solution to the power outage.

Torch.text: You use your torch to provide light and heat for the bakers, allowing them to continue preparing their delectable creations despite the power outage.

Cooling rack.text: You place the cooling rack over a lit candle, hoping it will support a pan and provide enough heat for baking, but the flimsy rack quickly overheats and warps, rendering it useless.

Cake stand.text: You attempt to reflect the meagre light from the storm using the shiny surface of the cake stand, angling it towards your workspace, but the flickering lightning provides only brief flashes of illumination, insufficient for the delicate work of decorating your showstopper.

Bent darning needle.text: Your attempt to use the bent darning needle to repair the old gas lamp fails miserably, as the needle is too thick to fit through the lamp's delicate components, leaving you fumbling in the dark.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to use the toffee-covered pastry brush as a makeshift candle, but the toffee quickly melts and drips onto the floor, making a sticky mess. The pastry brush is now coated in hardened toffee and unusable.

Lilac icing sugar.text: You attempt to use the lilac icing sugar to create a makeshift birthday candle, but the sugar fails to ignite and simply melts into a sticky puddle.

Dented Rolling Pin.text: You attempt to use the dented rolling pin to bash some flint and create sparks to light candles, but the pin snaps in half, leaving you without a light source or a rolling pin.

Edible Flowers.text: You attempt to use the edible flowers as a light source by setting them aflame, but they merely smoulder and produce an acrid smoke that fills the competition tent.

Matches.text: You frantically strike matches and attempt to weld the collapsed table back together, but succeed only in setting the tablecloth ablaze, adding further chaos to the scene.

Egg whisk.text: You frantically whisk together a mixture of eggs, flour, and sugar, hoping to create an impromptu glaze to hold the collapsed cakes together, but the mixture is far too runny and only makes the mess worse.

Wrench.text: You frantically attempt to repair the collapsed table with the wrench, but in your haste, you overtighten a bolt and snap the table leg clean off, making the situation even worse.

Icing sugar.text: You hastily sprinkle icing sugar over the collapsed cakes in a desperate attempt to salvage their appearance, but the sugary dusting only highlights the crumbled mess beneath.

Tongs.text: You quickly gather up the scattered bakes using the tongs, placing them on chairs, windowsills, and any other flat surface you can find to create an impromptu display.

Pastry brush.text: You frantically attempt to dust off the cakes with your pastry brush, but it's far too small to clean up the mess and does nothing to fix the collapsed table.

Wooden spoon.text: You attempt to prop up the collapsed table with your wooden spoon, but it snaps under the weight, and the baked goods end up even more hopelessly scattered across the ground.

Darning needle.text: You frantically grab your darning needle and attempt to stitch the collapsed table together, but the thin needle breaks under the weight of the heavy wooden planks, leaving you back at square one.

Plunger.text: You frantically attempt to prop up the collapsed table with the plunger, but it proves far too flimsy and unstable, causing even more cakes to tumble to the ground in a spectacularly sticky mess.

Rolling pin.text: You attempt to use the rolling pin as a makeshift support beam to prop up the collapsed table, but the weight of the cakes and pastries proves too much, causing the rolling pin to snap in half and the baked goods to tumble to the ground once more.

Screwdriver.text: You attempt to use the screwdriver to repair the table, but in your haste, you accidentally stab yourself in the hand. As you yelp in pain, you drop the screwdriver, which rolls under the collapsed table, out of reach.

Vinegar.text: You frantically splash vinegar onto the collapsed table in a misguided attempt to clean up the mess, but the strong smell only adds to the chaos and confusion.

Butter.text: You hastily slather butter on the collapsed table, hoping it will act as a lubricant to help the cakes slide into place, but instead, it creates a greasy mess that ruins the baked goods and makes the disaster even worse.

Hammer.text: You frantically hammer nails into the collapsed table in a misguided attempt to repair it, but your efforts only make the situation worse, reducing the table to a splintered mess.

Crochet hook.text: You frantically attempt to crochet the tablecloth back together with the hook, but the delicate lace quickly unravels, leaving you with a tangled mess and no solution.

Potato masher.text: You attempt to use the potato masher to prop up the collapsed table, but its flimsy wire handle immediately bends under the weight, sending the masher clattering to the floor amidst the ruined bakes.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to pick up the fallen cakes and pastries with tweezers, but the delicate baked goods crumble and fall apart, making an even bigger mess.

Jam spoon.text: You frantically scoop up cakes and pastries with the jam spoon, but they simply slide off the tiny utensil and plop back onto the ground, now even more worse for wear.

Pliers.text: You fumble with the pliers, trying to repair the collapsed table, but only succeed in mangling the metal joints further, rendering the table completely unusable.

Butter knife.text: You attempt to use the butter knife to prop up the collapsed table, but the flimsy utensil simply bends and snaps under the weight, leaving you back at square one.

Butter dish.text: You frantically grab the butter dish and attempt to prop up the collapsed table with it, but the dish is far too small and flimsy to support the weight, and it shatters into pieces.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You frantically wave your embroidered handkerchief in an attempt to catch the judges' attention, but they're too focused on the chaotic mess of cakes and pastries scattered across the ground to notice your futile efforts.

Sponge.text: You quickly grab a large sponge from your supplies and use it to mop up the worst of the spilt filling, saving the cakes from complete ruin and allowing the judging to proceed with only slightly worse for wear entries.

Mirror.text: You prop the mirror up against the collapsed table, hoping to at least create an attractive display, but the uneven ground causes it to topple over, shattering into countless shards and creating an even bigger mess.

Silver platter.text: You quickly gather up all the competition entries and artfully arrange them on your large silver platter, creating an impromptu display that showcases each baked good beautifully.

Lace doily.text: You quickly gather up the lace doilies from the tables and arrange them on the floor, creating an impromptu display area for the slightly worse-for-wear baked goods.

Thermometer.text: You frantically wave the thermometer around, trying to direct the attention of the panicked crowd, but in your haste, you accidentally fling it into a splattered cake on the ground.

Towel.text: You quickly spread out the towel on the ground and carefully arrange the cakes and pastries on top, creating an improvised display that showcases the baked goods beautifully.

Flowers.text: You hastily arrange the flowers on the ground in a circle around the collapsed table, but the delicate petals are quickly crushed underfoot by the milling crowd, and the wind scatters them far and wide.

Tray.text: You quickly gather up all the trays you have on hand and arrange them on the ground, creating a makeshift display area for the competition entries. The judges are impressed by your quick thinking and the competition proceeds without further disruption.

Oven gloves.text: You attempt to catch the falling baked goods with your oven gloves, but the mitts are too bulky and unwieldy, causing you to fumble and drop even more cakes.

Apron.text: You frantically gather up the scattered cakes and pastries, piling them haphazardly into your apron, but the flimsy fabric quickly gives way under the weight, dumping the baked goods back onto the ground in a sad, crumbled heap.

Dog treats.text: You hastily arrange the dog treats on a spare tablecloth, hoping to distract the judges, but they are unimpressed by the inedible display and disqualify you from the competition.

Ribbon.text: You quickly gather up the ribbons and tie them between the table legs, creating a makeshift hammock to catch the falling baked goods and prevent them from hitting the ground.

Whisk.text: You frantically whisk together a makeshift icing to glue the cakes back together, but the sticky mess only makes things worse, cementing the pastries into an inedible heap.

Mixing bowls.text: You turn over the mixing bowls and place them upside-down on the floor, arranging the cakes and pastries on top to create an impromptu tiered display.

Piping bag.text: You frantically attempt to pipe the cakes back together, but the delicate sponges crumble under the pressure, creating an even bigger mess.

Measuring cups.text: You quickly gather up the measuring cups and place them upside-down on the ground, forming a makeshift tiered display stand for the competition entries.

Flour.text: You hastily sprinkle flour over the ground, hoping it will somehow make the ruined cakes and pastries more presentable, but this only makes the mess worse, and you realise that flour alone cannot salvage the disaster.

Baking powder.text: You frantically sprinkle baking powder over the fallen cakes, hoping it will magically cause them to rise back onto the table, but alas, it merely adds an unappetising dusty coating to the splattered bakes.

Spanner.text: You attempt to use the spanner to repair the collapsed table, but your efforts only make things worse, causing the table to break apart completely and sending even more baked goods crashing to the ground.

Eggs.text: You frantically gather up the eggs from your bakery stall, intending to whip up a massive omelette to serve the judges, but in your haste, you trip and fall, splattering the eggs across the ground and yourself.

Torch.text: You shine your torch on the collapsed table, hoping to illuminate a solution, but the harsh shadows only make the mess of cakes and pastries look even more chaotic and unsalvageable.

Cooling rack.text: You quickly grab the cooling racks from your bakery stall and arrange them on the grass to create a makeshift display for the competition entries, saving the day with your quick thinking.

Cake stand.text: You quickly place your cake stand in the centre of the room and carefully arrange the undamaged competition entries on its tiers, creating an attractive impromptu display that saves the day.

Bent darning needle.text: You frantically attempt to stitch the display linens together with the bent darning needle to create a makeshift hammock for the baked goods, but the needle snaps and the linens rip apart, causing even more cakes to tumble to the ground.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to prop up the collapsed table with your toffee-covered pastry brush, but the flimsy utensil snaps under the weight, leaving you covered in sticky toffee and holding a broken brush.

Lilac icing sugar.text: You hastily sprinkle the lilac icing sugar over the collapsed cakes in a desperate attempt to make them more presentable, but it simply highlights the disastrous mess on the ground.

Dented Rolling Pin.text: You attempt to stack the cakes and pastries on the rolling pin like a makeshift serving platter, but its uneven surface causes them to roll off and splatter onto the ground in an even worse mess than before.

Edible Flowers.text: You frantically garnish the collapsed cakes with edible flowers, but the delicate blossoms are crushed under the weight of the ruined pastries, adding an unappetising floral mush to the disaster.

Oven Thermometer.text: You frantically wave the oven thermometer around, trying to direct the attention of the panicked crowd, but no one notices your futile efforts amidst the chaos of the collapsed table and ruined bakes.

Matches.text: You attempt to use the matches to caramelise the sugar on top of the cake, but you set the entire confection ablaze, filling the church with smoke and ruining the centrepiece.

Egg whisk.text: With your trusty egg whisk in hand, you whip up a light and airy sponge cake, layering it with homemade applesauce and cinnamon buttercream to capture the warm, comforting essence of Applebottom village. The congregation is delighted by the festive centrepiece, which fills the church with the inviting aroma of apples and spice.

Wrench.text: You attempt to use the wrench to craft an elaborate cake structure, but the heavy tool mangles the delicate sponge and sends buttercream splattering across the kitchen.

Icing sugar.text: You sift the icing sugar over the cooled cake layers, creating a snowy effect that captures the magical stillness of an Applebottom winter's eve. The simple yet elegant design, accented with marzipan holly leaves and sugared berries, perfectly embodies the heartfelt spirit of the village.

Tongs.text: You gingerly attempt to sculpt a cake using the tongs, but their unwieldy metal prongs merely mangle the delicate sponge and buttercream, leaving you with a sad, misshapen mess that in no way captures the spirit of Applebottom.

Pastry brush.text: You use the pastry brush to delicately apply a glaze of local Applebottom honey and cinnamon to the finished cake, creating a glistening, aromatic masterpiece that captures the warmth and sweetness of the village.

Wooden spoon.text: Using your trusty wooden spoon, you mix together a festive spiced cake batter fragrant with cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice, evoking warm memories of cosy Applebottom Christmases past. You skilfully sculpt the baked cake into a charming rendition of the village green, complete with marzipan cottages, fondant cobblestones, and a dusting of icing sugar snow, creating a delightful edible centrepiece that captures the heart and soul of Applebottom.

Darning needle.text: You attempt to use the darning needle to sculpt intricate designs on the cake, but your hands slip, marring the icing and leaving unsightly holes in the sponge.

Plunger.text: You attempt to fashion a festive cake using the plunger as a mould, but the resulting monstrosity is deemed unfit for human consumption, let alone as a centrepiece for the Christmas Eve service.

Rolling pin.text: You roll out a thin sheet of marzipan and use the rolling pin to emboss it with a relief of the village's charming streets and landmarks, then drape it over the cake to create an edible sculpture that captures Applebottom's essence.

Screwdriver.text: You attempt to use the screwdriver to carve intricate designs into the cake, but your efforts only succeed in mangling the delicate sponge and buttercream, leaving you with a decidedly un-festive mess.

Vinegar.text: You pour a generous glug of vinegar into the cake batter, hoping its tangy essence will somehow capture the spirit of Applebottom, but the resulting cake is a dense, mouth-puckering disaster that even the forgiving vicar can't bring himself to praise.

Butter.text: You skilfully blend the butter with sugar, flour, eggs, and applesauce to create a moist, flavourful cake batter, then pour it into a festive Christmas tree-shaped pan and bake until golden brown.

Hammer.text: You attempt to shape the cake using the hammer, but your enthusiastic pounding only succeeds in reducing the delicate sponge to a sad pile of crumbs.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to crochet an edible cake using the hook, but the resulting sugary tangle is completely inedible and unsuitable for the vicar's Christmas Eve service.

Potato masher.text: You attempt to mash boiled potatoes into a cake-like consistency using the masher, but the resulting gloopy mess fails to capture the essence of Applebottom or bring any festive cheer.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to decorate the cake with delicate icing details using the tweezers, but your hands shake and you end up with a sloppy, unappetising mess.

Jam spoon.text: You attempt to spread jam on the cake layers with the jam spoon, but the layers slide apart and the cake collapses into a sticky, fruity mess.

Pliers.text: You attempt to sculpt the cake using a pair of pliers, but the heavy-handed tool mangles the delicate sponge and buttercream, leaving you with a crumbled, inedible mess.

Butter knife.text: You attempt to sculpt an elaborate cake using only a butter knife, but the soft icing and delicate sponge prove too fiddly for the small blade, leaving you with a misshapen mess rather than a magnificent centrepiece.

Butter dish.text: You place a butter dish on the altar as your Christmas Eve centrepiece, but the congregation is unimpressed by the uninspired offering that fails to capture Applebottom's spirit.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You attempt to decorate the cake with the embroidered handkerchief, but the delicate fabric quickly becomes saturated with icing and tears apart, ruining both the handkerchief and the cake.

Sponge.text: You attempt to bake a cake using only a sponge, but the resulting dessert is dry, flavourless, and completely unsuitable as a festive centrepiece.

Mirror.text: You attempt to decorate the cake by placing a mirror on top, hoping it will reflect the congregation's joyful faces, but the hefty mirror sinks into the soft icing, ruining the centrepiece.

Silver platter.text: You place the silver platter on the table, ready to construct your cake, but its smooth surface provides no support for the delicate sponges, which slip and slide as you attempt to stack them, resulting in a lopsided, misshapen mess.

Lace doily.text: You attempt to decorate the cake with the lace doily, but the delicate fabric quickly becomes saturated with icing and tears apart, leaving an unsightly mess atop the centrepiece.

Thermometer.text: You attempt to use the thermometer to check the temperature of your cake batter, but in your haste, you accidentally drop it into the mixing bowl, shattering the glass and ruining the entire batch.

Towel.text: You attempt to fashion a cake shaped like Applebottom using only a towel, but the result is a sad, misshapen lump that fails to capture the village's spirit and would likely confuse the congregation.

Flowers.text: You arrange the flowers into a beautiful bouquet atop the cake, creating a charming design that captures the essence of Applebottom's gardens and green spaces. The delicate blooms and fresh greenery bring a natural beauty to the centrepiece cake that is sure to delight the congregation.

Tray.text: You arrange a selection of freshly baked treats on the tray to form a delightful tableau of Applebottom life, with iced biscuits depicting cherished village scenes and a centrepiece fruitcake adorned with marzipan villagers gathered around the town Christmas tree. The congregation is charmed by your creative and heartfelt cake design that perfectly captures the cosy spirit of the community.

Oven gloves.text: You slip on your trusty oven gloves and carefully remove the piping hot cake from the oven, a beautifully decorated confection that perfectly captures the warm, inviting spirit of Applebottom in every festive detail.

Apron.text: You attempt to capture the essence of Applebottom by hastily sketching a cake design on your apron, but the charcoal smudges and the result looks more like an eldritch horror than a festive treat.

Dog treats.text: You attempt to decorate the cake with dog treats, but the Vicar gently reminds you that they are neither appropriate nor appetising for the congregation.

Ribbon.text: You tie the ribbon into an elegant bow atop the cake, adding the perfect finishing touch to your delightful creation that captures the warmth and charm of Applebottom village.

Whisk.text: With a few deft flicks of your trusty whisk, you aerate the cake batter to perfection, resulting in a light and fluffy sponge that captures the warm, inviting essence of Applebottom village.

Mixing bowls.text: You gather your trusty mixing bowls and set to work, carefully selecting ingredients that evoke the heart and soul of Applebottom. With skilful blending and inspired flavour combinations, you create a magnificent cake that captures the very essence of the village, sure to bring joy to all who behold it.

Piping bag.text: With deft hands and a joyful heart, you craft an exquisite cake featuring the rolling hills, quaint cottages, and apple orchards of Applebottom in delicate buttercream, using your trusty piping bag to capture every charming detail. The congregation is enchanted by your delectable work of art, and the Vicar declares it a true embodiment of the village's spirit.

Measuring cups.text: You carefully measure out the ingredients for a moist, spiced applesauce cake that fills the church hall with the warm, comforting aroma of cinnamon, nutmeg, and clove - the very essence of Applebottom at Christmastime.

Flour.text: You sift the flour and carefully measure out the other ingredients, determined to create a cake that will fill the villagers with joy. After hours of mixing, baking, and delicately assembling the tiers, you step back to admire your stunning creation - a towering masterpiece adorned with fondant sculptures of Applebottom's most beloved landmarks, from the quaint cottage gardens to the ancient village oak.

Baking powder.text: You sift the baking powder into your cake batter, folding it in gently to create a light, fluffy sponge that will rise beautifully in the oven, forming the perfect base for your Applebottom-inspired Christmas centrepiece.

Spanner.text: You attempt to sculpt the cake using the spanner as a makeshift frosting spatula, but the resulting mess looks more like a mechanic's workshop mishap than a festive dessert.

Eggs.text: You whisk the eggs into a rich batter, folding in grated apples and warm spices to create a moist, fragrant cake that embodies the cosy charm of Applebottom village.

Torch.text: You attempt to use the torch to caramelise the sugar on top of the cake, but the intense heat chars the icing and sets off the smoke alarm, filling the vicarage kitchen with an acrid haze.

Cooling rack.text: You place the cooled gingerbread on the cooling rack, arranging the pieces to form a beautiful replica of St Bede's Church, complete with stained glass windows of coloured icing.

Cake stand.text: You carefully arranged the ingredients and decorations on the cake stand, building up tiers of delectable sponge, buttercream, and marzipan to create a stunning edible tableau depicting the heart and soul of Applebottom village. The resulting masterpiece, proudly displayed on its stand, drew gasps of delight from the congregation and made the Christmas Eve service truly unforgettable.

Biscuit tin.text: You attempt to bake the cake in the biscuit tin, but the tin is far too small and shallow. The cake batter overflows, creating a smoky mess in your oven and leaving you with a sad, blackened disc that in no way captures the spirit of Applebottom.

Twine.text: You attempt to craft an Applebottom-inspired cake using twine, but the string proves far too thin and weak to support the layers. The resulting mess resembles a pile of sweet spaghetti more than a festive centrepiece.

Honey.text: You drizzle the honey over the top of the cake, hoping to add a touch of sweetness, but it soaks in and vanishes without a trace, leaving the cake looking plain and uninspired.

Foil.text: You attempt to sculpt a cake topper from foil, but the delicate material tears and crumples, leaving you with a misshapen blob rather than a recognisable Applebottom landmark.

Lace.text: You decide to decorate the cake with intricate lace patterns, but the delicate lace quickly absorbs the moisture from the icing and becomes a soggy, inedible mess.

Plastic wrap.text: You wrap the entire cake in plastic wrap, but it sticks to the icing and tears off in pieces when you try to remove it, ruining the cake's appearance.

Cotton wool.text: You attempt to sculpt an Applebottom-inspired cake using cotton wool, but the fluffy fibres refuse to hold any shape and quickly disintegrate into a sad, inedible mess, leaving you covered in sticky clumps of wool and icing.

Nutmeg.text: You sprinkle nutmeg into the cake batter, but the spice's subtle flavour is completely overpowered by the other ingredients, failing to capture Applebottom's essence.

Cellophane sheets.text: You wrap the cake layers in cellophane, but the thin plastic sheets do nothing to enhance the cake's appearance or tie it to the village's spirit. The cake looks clinical and uninspired, and Vicar Percival is deeply disappointed.

Egg whites.text: You whip the egg whites into a fluffy meringue, creating delicate snow-capped peaks atop your spiced applesauce cake layers that evoke the rolling hills and quaint cottages of Applebottom dusted with fresh snow.

Toothpicks.text: You attempt to construct an elaborate cake sculpture using only toothpicks, but it quickly collapses into a sad, splintery heap that even the church mice turn their noses up at.

Candy canes.text: You attempt to decorate the cake with candy canes, but their hard, sharp edges pierce the soft sponge, causing the cake to collapse into a sad, sticky heap.

Wax.text: You attempted to sculpt the cake using wax, but the heat from your hands caused it to melt into a misshapen blob, leaving you with a waxy mess instead of a festive centrepiece.

Cinnamon.text: You bake a decadent applesauce spice cake laced with cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves, topped with a luscious cinnamon cream cheese frosting. The warm, comforting aroma of cinnamon evokes memories of cosy winter evenings by the fire and fills the church with the spirit of Applebottom.

Bent darning needle.text: You attempt to sculpt the cake using the bent darning needle as a makeshift tool, but the delicate sponge crumbles and the icing smears, resulting in a misshapen mess rather than a festive masterpiece.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: You attempt to use the toffee-covered pastry brush to add decorative flourishes to the cake, but the hardened toffee proves too inflexible and your efforts mar the cake's surface.

Lilac icing sugar.text: You sift the lilac icing sugar over the cake, creating a delicate dusting that evokes the soft purple hues of Applebottom's famous lilac fields, infusing the centrepiece with the essence of the village's natural beauty and capturing the spirit of the community.

Dented Rolling Pin.text: You attempt to roll out the cake dough with the dented rolling pin, but the uneven surface results in a lumpy, misshapen mess that fails to capture the spirit of Applebottom.

Edible Flowers.text: You artfully decorate the cake with the edible flowers, creating a charming garden scene that captures the quaint beauty and warm spirit of Applebottom village.

Oven Thermometer.text: You carefully monitored the oven temperature with your trusty thermometer to ensure the cake baked evenly, resulting in a moist, golden sponge that perfectly captured the warmth and cosiness of Applebottom village.

Matches.text: In an attempt to caramelise the gingerbread, you light a match and hold it under each biscuit, but the flame singes your fingers and the biscuits end up charred and bitter.

Egg whisk.text: You use the egg whisk to crush the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into a fine crumb, which you then mix with melted butter, spices, and a touch of brandy to create a delightful gingerbread biscuit base for mini cheesecakes topped with a dollop of cranberry sauce.

Wrench.text: You attempt to use the wrench to crush the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into crumbs, but the wrench's weight and awkward shape make the task inefficient and messy, leaving you with a mix of inconsistently sized pieces and a dusting of gingerbread debris on your worktop.

Icing sugar.text: You carefully break the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into small pieces and mix them with icing sugar to create a delightful crumble topping for a batch of freshly baked muffins, delighting the congregation with your resourcefulness and creativity.

Tongs.text: You attempt to use the tongs to remove the overbaked gingerbread biscuits from the baking tray, but the tongs are too large and unwieldy, causing you to accidentally crush the delicate biscuits into crumbs.

Pastry brush.text: You deftly use the pastry brush to apply a light glaze of honey and sprinkle the biscuits with chopped candied ginger, transforming them into a delightful twist on traditional gingerbread that's met with delight by the congregation.

Wooden spoon.text: You attempt to crush the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into crumbs using the wooden spoon, but the biscuits are far too hard, and the spoon splinters and breaks under the force.

Darning needle.text: You attempt to poke holes in the overbaked gingerbread biscuits with the darning needle to make them more appealing, but the needle snaps in half, leaving you with a mess of crumbs and broken needles.

Plunger.text: In a misguided attempt to salvage the overbaked gingerbread, you use the plunger to squash the biscuits into a dense, unappetising paste, which sadly proves inedible and must be binned.

Rolling pin.text: You attempt to crush the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into crumbs using the rolling pin, but they're so hard that the rolling pin snaps in half, leaving you with a mess of broken wood and burnt biscuit shards.

Screwdriver.text: You attempt to flatten the overbaked gingerbread biscuits with the screwdriver, but the brittle biscuits crumble into an unappetising mess of crumbs and metal shavings.

Vinegar.text: In an attempt to salvage the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, you generously splash vinegar onto them, hoping the acidity will somehow magically revive their texture and flavour. Unfortunately, the congregation is now faced with unappetisingly soggy, vinegar-soaked biscuits that taste even worse than before.

Butter.text: You soften a generous amount of butter and spread it over the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, transforming them into delightfully rich and crispy gingersnaps that are a hit with the congregation.

Hammer.text: You enthusiastically take the hammer to the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, but your vigorous hammering reduces them to an unappetising pile of crumbs, unsuitable for serving to the congregation.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to use the crochet hook to poke holes in the gingerbread biscuits, hoping to create a lacy, decorative effect. However, the biscuits are too hard and the hook keeps snapping, leaving you with a handful of broken hooks and a plate of cracked, unsightly biscuits.

Potato masher.text: You attempt to mash the gingerbread biscuits with the potato masher, but the hard biscuits resist the masher's blunt force, resulting in a crumbly, unappetising mess.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to carefully position each overcooked gingerbread biscuit with the tweezers, but the brittle biscuits crumble and break apart, leaving you with a pile of unappetising crumbs.

Jam spoon.text: You attempt to spread jam over the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, but the tough exterior causes the jam spoon to snap in half, leaving you with a sticky mess and broken utensil.

Pliers.text: You attempt to use the pliers to break the gingerbread biscuits into smaller, more aesthetically pleasing pieces, but the tough, overbaked biscuits prove too strong for the tool, causing the pliers to bend and break under the strain.

Butter knife.text: You attempt to slice the rock-hard gingerbread biscuits into festive shapes using the butter knife, but the brittle blade snaps under the pressure, leaving you with a handful of broken biscuit pieces and a useless knife handle.

Butter dish.text: You place the gingerbread biscuits in the butter dish, hoping the residual butter will soften them, but instead they absorb the butter and become an unappetising, greasy mess.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You attempt to cover the burnt biscuits with your embroidered handkerchief, but the delicate fabric quickly becomes scorched and tattered from the heat, ruining both the biscuits and the handkerchief.

Sponge.text: You frantically dab the rock-hard gingerbread biscuits with a damp sponge, hoping to soften them, but the sponge merely disintegrates against their unyielding surface, leaving a trail of soggy crumbs.

Mirror.text: You attempt to use the mirror to reflect sunlight onto the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, hoping to caramelise them, but the intense heat shatters the mirror into countless sharp shards.

Silver platter.text: You arrange the overbaked gingerbread biscuits artfully on the silver platter, surrounding them with a festive garland of holly sprigs and bright red berries, creating an eye-catching centrepiece that draws praise from the congregation.

Lace doily.text: You place the delicate lace doily atop the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, hoping to disguise their imperfections, but the intricate lace pattern quickly becomes lost in the dark, crisp surface of the biscuits, failing to elevate their appearance.

Thermometer.text: You attempt to use the thermometer to gauge the temperature of the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, but the thermometer's range is inadequate for measuring such high temperatures, leaving you no closer to a solution.

Towel.text: You attempt to wrap the overbaked gingerbread biscuits in a towel to soften them, but the biscuits are so hard that they tear holes in the fabric, leaving you with a shredded towel and inedible crumbs.

Flowers.text: You attempt to decorate the overbaked gingerbread biscuits with delicate flower petals, but the dry, crumbly texture causes the petals to fall off, leaving a disappointing mess.

Tray.text: You arrange the overbaked gingerbread biscuits on the tray in an attractive pattern, creating a festive and rustic Christmas display that delights the congregation.

Oven gloves.text: You put on your oven gloves and carefully remove the overbaked gingerbread biscuits from the oven, but no matter how you arrange them on the cooling rack, they still look unappetisingly dark and crisp.

Apron.text: You attempt to use your apron to shield the overbaked biscuits from view as you carry them out to the congregation, but the distinct burnt aroma wafting from beneath the fabric gives the game away.

Dog treats.text: You crumble the dog treats into the overbaked gingerbread biscuit crumbs, mix in some icing, and shape the mixture into festive shapes. Unfortunately, the dog treat flavour is far too strong and the strange smell puts off the congregation.

Ribbon.text: You attempt to tie the gingerbread biscuits together with ribbon to create a festive garland, but the brittle biscuits crumble and break apart, leaving you with a mess of crumbs and tangled ribbon.

Whisk.text: You whisk the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into fine crumbs, then mix them with melted butter, cinnamon, and sugar to create a delectable crumble topping for a warm apple compote, turning a potential disaster into a delightful Christmas treat that impresses the congregation.

Mixing bowls.text: You crush the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into crumbs using the mixing bowls, then mix the crumbs with melted butter, sugar, and spices to create a delectable gingerbread biscuit base for a luscious Christmas trifle.

Piping bag.text: You skilfully pipe an elegant lattice pattern onto the gingerbread biscuits using royal icing, transforming them into beautiful decorative pieces that will proudly adorn the church's Christmas tree.

Measuring cups.text: You carefully crush the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into fine crumbs using your measuring cups, then layer the crumbs with whipped cream and festive berries in small glass jars to create charming individual trifles that are a hit with the congregation.

Flour.text: You crumble the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into a fine powder and mix it with flour to create a delightful crumble topping for a comforting apple crumble, which is sure to impress the congregation.

Baking powder.text: In a misguided attempt to revive the overbaked biscuits, you mixed baking powder into your icing, hoping it would soften them, but the chemical reaction caused the icing to bubble and froth, ruining the biscuits entirely.

Spanner.text: You attempt to use the spanner to break the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into smaller pieces, but the hard biscuits prove too tough and instead damage the spanner's jaws, rendering it useless.

Eggs.text: You crumble the gingerbread biscuits into a fine powder and mix it with eggs, flour, and butter to create a delectable gingerbread-flavoured shortbread that's a hit at the church fête.

Torch.text: You attempt to caramelise the gingerbread biscuits' surfaces with the torch, but the intense heat chars them beyond recognition, filling the kitchen with an acrid burnt smell.

Cooling rack.text: You arrange the overbaked gingerbread biscuits on the cooling rack in an artful pattern, creating a unique and eye-catching centrepiece for the congregation's Christmas gathering.

Cake stand.text: You arrange the overbaked gingerbread biscuits on the cake stand in an artful spiral, dusting them with icing sugar to create a rustic, yet elegant, Christmas centrepiece that delights the congregation.

Biscuit tin.text: You carefully break the overbaked gingerbread biscuits into small pieces and layer them in a festive biscuit tin, alternating with generous dollops of homemade brandy butter, creating a delightful and indulgent Christmas trifle-inspired treat.

Twine.text: You attempt to tie the gingerbread biscuits together with twine to create a rustic Christmas ornament, but the biscuits crumble and fall apart, leaving you with a mess of crumbs and tangled string.

Honey.text: You drizzle the overbaked gingerbread biscuits with honey, creating a delightful glaze that softens their texture and adds a delectable sweetness, transforming them into a scrumptious treat for the congregation.

Foil.text: You wrap the overbaked gingerbread biscuits in foil, hoping to soften them, but the heat trapped inside only makes them even harder and more unappetising.

Lace.text: You attempt to decorate the overbaked gingerbread biscuits with delicate lace, but the intricate patterns are lost on the dark, crispy surface, resulting in a confusing and unappealing mess.

Plastic wrap.text: You attempt to wrap the overbaked gingerbread biscuits in plastic wrap, hoping to soften them, but the heat from the biscuits melts the plastic, creating an inedible, sticky mess.

Cotton wool.text: You attempt to disguise the burnt biscuits by wrapping them in cotton wool to resemble miniature sheep, but the wool quickly catches fire in the oven, filling the bakery with an acrid smell of singed fluff.

Nutmeg.text: You grind the nutmeg into a fine powder and sprinkle it generously over the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, creating a fragrant and festive aroma that complements the spicy ginger notes.

Cellophane sheets.text: You attempt to wrap the overbaked gingerbread biscuits in cellophane sheets, but the brittle biscuits crumble and break apart as you handle them, leaving you with a mess of crumbs and shattered cellophane.

Egg whites.text: You whip the egg whites into a light, fluffy meringue and gently fold it into the crushed gingerbread biscuits, creating a delightful gingerbread-meringue parfait that's a hit with the congregation.

Toothpicks.text: Attempting to use the toothpicks as supports, you carefully arrange them between the overbaked gingerbread biscuits to create a precarious tower, but as you place the final biscuit on top, the entire structure collapses, sending toothpicks and crumbs flying across the kitchen.

Candy canes.text: You skilfully crush the candy canes into a fine powder and sprinkle it over the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, creating a delightful peppermint crunch that complements the spicy flavour perfectly.

Wax.text: You attempt to mould the wax into festive shapes to decorate the burnt biscuits, but the wax refuses to adhere to the brittle surface and instead flakes off in unappealing clumps.

Cinnamon.text: You crush the cinnamon sticks into a fine powder and sprinkle it generously over the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, creating a delightfully aromatic and festive treat that the congregation will surely enjoy.

Bent darning needle.text: You attempt to poke holes in the gingerbread biscuits with the bent darning needle to make them look more decorative, but the needle gets stuck and snaps in half, embedding itself in one of the biscuits.

toffee-covered pastry brush.text: In your attempt to salvage the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, you brush them with toffee using the pastry brush, but the toffee fails to adhere properly to the dry, crumbly surface, resulting in an unappetising, sticky mess.

Lilac icing sugar.text: You sift the lilac icing sugar over the gingerbread biscuits, creating a delicate, sweet coating that softens their overbaked crispness and lends a festive, floral note to the treats.

Dented Rolling Pin.text: You attempt to flatten the overbaked gingerbread biscuits with the dented rolling pin, but the uneven surface only crumbles the brittle biscuits into an unsalvageable mess.

Edible Flowers.text: You carefully arrange the edible flowers on top of the overbaked gingerbread biscuits, creating a charming and rustic design that draws the eye away from their slightly too-crisp texture.

Oven Thermometer.text: The oven thermometer confirms the gingerbread biscuits are indeed overbaked, but sadly, it provides no insight on how to revive them into a delightful treat.

Charcoal-Smudged Apron.text: You hastily wipe the charred biscuits with your apron, but it only makes matters worse by breaking them into sooty crumbs. The once-delightful gingerbread is now completely inedible, covered in a layer of greasy charcoal dust from your well-worn baking garment.

Matches.text: You attempt to tie the matches together into a festive garland, but they snap and scatter across the floor, creating a fire hazard.

Egg whisk.text: You attempt to tie the ribbon around your baked goods using the egg whisk, but it tangles hopelessly and tears the delicate packaging.

Wrench.text: You attempt to use the wrench to bend some scrap metal into festive shapes for packaging, but you just end up with a mess of twisted metal and a sore wrist.

Icing sugar.text: You attempt to frost the treats with the icing sugar to make them look more festive, but the dusting of white powder fails to capture the holiday magic you were hoping for.

Tongs.text: You attempt to tie the ribbon around your baked goods using the tongs, but the ribbons keep slipping and the packages look messy and unprofessional.

Pastry brush.text: You attempt to tie the pastry brush to the packages with string, but the bristles keep getting in the way and the brush is too bulky to create an attractive bow. The packages look messy and unprofessional, so you'll have to find another way to add a festive touch.

Wooden spoon.text: You attempt to tie the ribbon around your baked goods using the wooden spoon, but it proves far too clumsy for the delicate task, leaving you with a crumpled mess.

Darning needle.text: You use the darning needle to carefully stitch together scraps of cloth and lace to create rustic yet charming pouches and bows for your Christmas treats.

Plunger.text: You attempt to tie festive ribbons around your baked goods using the plunger's wooden handle, but it proves far too bulky and awkward to achieve the delicate, decorative effect you desire.

Rolling pin.text: You attempt to use the rolling pin to flatten some scrap paper into makeshift ribbon, but the result is a crumpled, uneven mess that won't tie properly around the boxes.

Screwdriver.text: You try to use a screwdriver to poke holes in a spare box lid to create a decorative pattern, but your efforts only result in an unappealing, perforated mess.

Vinegar.text: You attempt to tie festive bows using strips of paper soaked in vinegar, but the acidic liquid causes the paper to disintegrate and leaves an unpleasant odour on your baked goods.

Butter.text: You attempt to use the butter as an adhesive to fasten colourful paper scraps around your baked goods, but the greasy mess simply slides off, leaving an unappetising sheen.

Hammer.text: You attempt to hammer the ribbon and boxes together into a festive package, but your enthusiastic hammering only succeeds in smashing the delicate confections to crumbs.

Crochet hook.text: You attempt to use the crochet hook to weave together makeshift ribbons from spare bits of yarn, but your efforts result in a tangled mess that's more knotty than nice.

Potato masher.text: You attempt to mash potatoes with the masher to create a sticky paste for sealing boxes, but the resulting goop proves far too messy and unsuitable for the task.

Tweezers.text: You attempt to use the tweezers to precisely arrange scraps of paper and fabric into festive bows, but your hands shake from too much coffee and the materials keep slipping from the tweezers' grasp.

Jam spoon.text: You attempt to tie a festive bow around your treat boxes using the jam spoon, but the slippery utensil proves utterly unsuitable for the task, leaving you with a sticky mess and packages adorned with globs of jam.

Pliers.text: You attempt to use the pliers to crimp together makeshift ribbons from strips of aluminium foil, but the results are sharp, crinkly, and decidedly unfestive.

Butter knife.text: You attempt to use the butter knife to cut and fold some spare parchment paper into festive boxes, but the knife is too dull and the paper too thick, resulting in a pile of crumpled, torn scraps.

Butter dish.text: You attempt to arrange your baked treats in the butter dish, but the result looks greasy and unappetising, and certainly not festive.

Embroidered handkerchief.text: You carefully unfold your embroidered handkerchief and wrap it around each treat, tying the corners together with a bit of twine to create a charming, rustic package.

Sponge.text: You attempt to cut the sponge into festive shapes to tie onto your baked goods with string, but the results are a crumbly, soggy mess.

Mirror.text: You attempt to use the mirror to reflect light onto the treats, hoping it will make them sparkle festively. However, the reflected light is too harsh and washes out the colours, making the confections look pale and unappealing.

Silver platter.text: You arrange an assortment of your finest treats on the silver platter, creating an elegant display that captures the festive spirit without the need for ribbons or boxes.

Lace doily.text: You carefully unravel the delicate lace doily and use it to wrap your baked treats, tying each package with a simple ribbon to create an elegant, vintage-inspired presentation.

Thermometer.text: You attempt to fasten ribbon around your baked goods using the thermometer, but it proves far too inflexible and keeps rolling off the curved surfaces.

Towel.text: You attempt to wrap the baked goods in a tea towel, but the package looks sloppy and unprofessional, so you discard the idea.

Flowers.text: You artfully arrange the flowers into charming posies, tying them with leftover twine to adorn your treat boxes with a rustic, festive flair.

Tray.text: You arrange the treats artfully on the shiny metal tray, then tie a festive bow around it using ribbon scraps from your sewing basket.

Oven gloves.text: You attempt to tie your oven gloves around the treats as festive packaging, but the bulky gloves make the parcels look lumpy and absurd rather than elegantly wrapped.

Apron.text: You attempt to fashion makeshift boxes and ribbons from your apron, but the flimsy fabric proves unsuitable for securely packaging your baked goods.

Dog treats.text: You attempt to fashion the dog treats into festive shapes and tie them up with string, but the results look rather sad and unappetising, not fit for human consumption.

Ribbon.text: You find a spool of red ribbon tucked away in a drawer. With some careful measuring and snipping, you tie the ribbon into charming bows to adorn your treat boxes, adding a festive touch that will delight your customers.

Whisk.text: You attempt to affix ribbons to your baked goods using the whisk, but only succeed in making a tangled mess of ribbon and metal wire.

Mixing bowls.text: You attempt to stack your baked treats in mixing bowls and tie ribbons around them, but the results are hopelessly lopsided and keep toppling over.

Piping bag.text: You fill the piping bag with leftover icing and use it to pipe decorative bows and ribbons onto the treat boxes, creating a festive look without the need for actual ribbon.

Measuring cups.text: You try to use the measuring cups as festive boxes, but the treats fall right through the open bottoms, making a mess on the floor.

Flour.text: You sprinkle flour on the Christmas treats in an attempt to make them look festive and snowy, but the effect is underwhelming and messy.

Baking powder.text: You sprinkle baking powder on the treats in an attempt to give them a festive, snowy appearance, but the effect is underwhelming and messy.

Spanner.text: You attempt to fasten ribbons and adorn boxes using the spanner, but its ungainly shape and weight make it utterly unsuitable for delicate packaging tasks, leaving your baked goods in a sorry state.

Eggs.text: You attempt to use the eggs as an adhesive to stick together make-shift boxes from scraps of paper, but the results are a soggy, eggy mess.

Torch.text: You attempt to fashion a festive bow out of the torch's electrical cord, but end up with a tangled mess and a non-functional torch.

Cooling rack.text: You attempt to fasten ribbon and boxes to the cooling rack, but they slip through the gaps and onto the floor, leaving you with a mess instead of festive packaging.

Cake stand.text: You carefully arrange the treats on the cake stand, artfully draping a lace doily over the edge to lend a festive air.

Biscuit tin.text: You carefully arrange an assortment of your finest biscuits and sweets in the festive biscuit tin, creating a delightful and giftable treat box for the Christmas Eve service.

Twine.text: You artfully wrap the ribbon-less boxes with twine in a charming cross-hatch pattern, giving them a rustic, heartwarming appearance perfect for the festive occasion.

Honey.text: You attempt to affix honey to the treats as a festive garnish, but it slowly oozes off, leaving a sticky mess on your worktop.

Foil.text: You carefully wrap each holiday treat in shiny foil, then artfully arrange them in baskets lined with spare tea towels, creating a charming and festive presentation.
